Multi-function shows you a dashboard with controls at left (turning) and right (forward, reverse). Multi-function gives you easy access to a series of driving challenges (e.g., hairpin turn, etc.).

The build itself is NOT particularly easy. The instructions are clear, but there are places where it's tricky to insert everything correctly. Once built, the Technic model is rock-solid--it won't come apart, even when you drive the vehicle over obstacles, or off a 4‚Äù high ‚Äúcliff‚Äù. (As with any Technic model, you should check each step of assembly carefully, because Technic elements don't come apart easily when you make a mistake.)

There are three different motors in the model. They are powered by six (6) AAA batteries (not included). The vehicle is definitely NOT underpowered. The kit includes a big sheet of stickers, which are reasonably easy to apply. The vehicle shell is NOT printed at all--all of the orange/yellow patterning and sponsor ads come from stickers.

title: Terrific Display Model; White-on-Black Building Instructions Are Hard to Read
text:
This LEGO ARCHITECTURE SKYLINES: TOKYO 21051 BUILDING KIT (New 2020 ; 547 Pieces) took me longer to assemble than it should have, because the building instructions are printed in white on a black background. The model's base uses black LEGO pieces, so you need very good light to decipher the white-on-black drawings at the beginning. I've assembled numerous LEGO sets, but had to restart this one after seriously misinterpreting the instructions for the base.

Other than that, the Tokyo architecture model is interesting and fun. There is quite a bit of studs-not-on top assembly, and there are some very innovative connective techniques. Happily, the elements are printed with the graphics (no stickers to apply).

Thanks to the innovative, amazing architecture that exists in real-life Tokyo, the finished model makes a terrific display piece. For some reason, I really like the back wall of the model, which represents Mount Fuji. The finished model is small enough to fit easily into a bookcase or wall-mounted display case.

The instruction booklet includes photographs of the actual Tokyo buildings that are represented. In addition, short text paragraphs (in English, French, and Spanish) explain the functions and backgrounds of the buildings.

title: Starter Set With Well-Chosen Variety of Standard LEGO Elements
text:
This LEGO CLASSIC CREATIVE BLUE BRICKS 11006 KIDS' STARTER SET (New 2020 (52 Pieces)) is a very small building set, but it has an extremely well-chosen variety of LEGO elements. The bargain-priced set (under $5 on Amazon) has all the pieces for any of the three critters shown on the box. (In my photo, the whale's transparent blue waterspout is mostly hidden under a black brick at the lower right.)

Printed step-by-step building instructions for the critters are included in the box. Better yet, the set has enough varied elements to allow kids to rebuild the suggested models into small creatures or models of their own design. Adults can use this small set as a relaxing ‚Äúfiddle‚Äù set.

The all-blue set is a great way to introduce LEGO to someone new. If the person enjoys playing with LEGO elements, then he/she can invest in larger sets later.

The set contains standard LEGO pieces that are compatible with all LEGO building sets except DUPLO. (DUPLO sets are intended for very young children, and have extra-large bricks and pieces.)

title: Play Cube Displays Emma's Studio for Pet Grooming, Photography
text:
This LEGO FRIENDS EMMA'S PLAY CUBE 41404 BUILDING KIT (New 2020 (36 Pieces)) will be appreciated by any kid or adult who loves miniatures and dollhouses. It isn't much of a building kit, because there are only 36 pieces (including the doll, the surprise animal, the mirror, the hairbrush, the scissors, etc.). Because it contains only a few classic LEGO elements, any creative play must come from doll play rather than from rebuilding the elements into something different.

Of the three play cubes that I've assembled, Emma's is my least favorite. The cube depicts a pet grooming and photography studio, so the furnishings are kind of static. There is a mirror, a little laptop computer (a sticker gives it a display showing a choice of styles for the ‚Äúclient‚Äù), a camera on a stand, and a table for a pet to sit on during a photography session. The right-hand half of the cube has a great background sticker showing a window with a view of the Eiffel Tower.

The ‚Äúsurprise‚Äù consists of a cat figure in one of four colors (red, teal, gold, lavender). I love the fact that this series has the same ‚Äúsurprise‚Äù animal in each themed cube, the ‚Äúsurprise‚Äù being the color of the animal. This way there is no real pressure to ‚Äúcollect them all‚Äú when it comes to the ‚Äúsurprises‚Äù.

title: Charming Unisex Tow Truck Feels Solid, Satisfying to Push
text:
Because I love all LEGO building kits for heavy construction equipment (e.g., [[ASIN:B07Y8T4WHC LEGO Mobile Crane]]), I couldn't resist this cute little LEGO DUPLO MY FIRST TOW TRUCK 10918 (New 2020 (6 Pieces)). It's absolutely charming, all 6 pieces of it!

I really like the drivers' windows, with a boy on one side and a girl on the other. It makes this into a truly unisex toy. I love the big blue traffic cone that fits between the drivers' cabin and the moveable crane for transport. Tow trucks always set out traffic cones, for safety, when they're readying a tow. The crane itself is fun because it swings up and down freely.

The building instructions are on the outside of the retail box. The toy takes about 30 seconds for an adult to assemble, as the wheels are already attached to the truck base. When the toy is finished, it makes a terrific truck for general play. The wheels turn freely, and the truck feels solid and satisfying when it's pushed around.

Inside the box is a printed city street layout. The paper is very thin, so this won't last long unless it's glued to some sort of heavier backing. However the street layout fits the assembled tow truck, and is a nice detail.

Note that this is a LEGO duplo model, intended for very young children. The pieces are much larger than standard LEGO pieces. They are compatible with other duplo building sets, but NOT with standard LEGO elements.

title: Cute, Portable Toy With Miniature Pastry Chef Has Lots of Play Potential
text:
With only 44 pieces, this LEGO FRIENDS STEPHANIE'S PLAY CUBE Building Kit (New 2020 (44 Pieces)) isn't much of a building kit, but the finished project is a cute, portable toy that has a lot of play potential. I love it because I love dollhouses and miniatures.

When you open the finished cube, chef Stephanie is there in her bakery/kitchen, alongside a beautifully decorated cake. (Decorating the cake is a fun part of the build.) She has cupcakes in the oven, and white icing is cooking on the stove. Her little dog is there, too, watching the whole operation.

There are really two builds in the cube, one in each half. Both can be pulled out of the cube and placed on a table or countertop for play. The oven door opens so you can remove the cupcakes, and the drawer underneath the cake holds extra decorations (flowers and bows).

The background of the right half of the cube is supplied by a sticker that shows an apron hanging up, and a kitchen stool, among other things. Only two stickers (the background just mentioned, and the oven door detail) need to be applied to LEGO elements as part of the ‚Äústory‚Äù. There are extra stickers to be used however the builder chooses.

Something that I love about this play cube series, is that the ‚Äúsurprise‚Äù for each set is always the same animal, but in one of four different colors. In this set 41401, the animal is a dog that may be red, gold, teal, or lavender. I like my red dog, and am glad there is no real pressure to ‚Äúcollect them all‚Äú when it comes to the "surprise‚Äù, because it's only a matter of which color dog you get.

title: Smaller, Simpler Version of LEGO Pop-Up Book Tells Mulan's Story
text:
As a child, I loved pop-up books, so of course I love all of the LEGO pop-up book building kits. The first one (see [[ASIN:B07GYB8D34 LEGO Pop-Up Book]] originated as a fan model submitted to the LEGO Ideas fan-voting site (if you want to participate, just google for LEGO Ideas). This DISNEY MULAN'S STORYBOOK ADVENTURES 43174 BUILDING KIT (New 2020 (124 Pieces)) is a smaller, simpler version of the original pop-up book, but it's still a lot of fun.

The basic pop-up feature is the arched bridge that goes from the center--the book's stationary spine, where Mulan's buildings are--to the little ‚Äútea service‚Äù island in the left half of the book. The bridge goes up and down on a LEGO hinge, and snaps into place when the book is completely open.

There are LEGO studs strategically placed around the open book, so that the three dolls, Mulan's pony, and Mulan's cricket cage can all be firmly attached at once. This way, they don't rattle around loose (or get lost) when the book is closed to be put away. When the book is open for play, the dolls fit on the bridge, under the arches, and can stand anywhere on the book surface.

The assembly instructions are reasonably easy to follow--just look closely at the pictures. I had to take my book covers apart and reassemble them because I got the left (blue water) and right (white land) sides switched, so that the water was on the wrong side when the book was opened.

There are quite a few stickers, but only a few that need to be carefully placed on LEGO elements. The instructions aren't terribly clear on where to place the stickers that go onto the book's interior surfaces (e.g., the swimming Koi fish, the lily pads, Mulan's bed roll, the campfire, the cooking supplies). You can consult the box photos, or even the photos in the online LEGO Shop, if you want extra guidance for these.

One of my favorite features is the two little tassels or bells that swing from Mulan's temple-like building. I don't know whether this is an entirely new LEGO element, or whether it has appeared in other sets, but it was new to me. There are enough LEGO pieces in the set to make the book interesting to assemble; and the book is fun to play with after it's built.

title: Baseplate for Creating LEGO Snow Scenes
text:
Every LEGO building project begins with a baseplate. This LEGO CLASSIC WHITE BASEPLATE 11010 CREATIVE TOY FOR KIDS (New 2020 (1 Piece)) is the one you need for creating snow scenes (e.g., ski chalets, variants on the ‚ÄúFrozen‚Äù sets, etc.). It works with standard LEGO elements (not Duplo).

What you get is just a flat baseplate. You have to supply the rest of the LEGO elements for whatever you want to build.

title: Cute Ferrari Building Toy; Youngest Children May Need Some Adult Help
text:
This LEGO SPEED CHAMPIONS 76895 FERRARI F8 TRIBUTO BUILDING KIT (New 2020 (275 Pieces)) is recommended for ages 7 and up, but very young children may need some adult help with this kit. It takes some hand strength to add the tires to the hubs; and there are quite a few small left-oriented and right-oriented pieces that have to be placed just so, or the bodywork won't curve correctly (see my closeup photo).

The finished Ferrari is cute, and solidly built for play. The top comes off so that the minifig can sit inside. There are no car doors that swing open (a feature that is standard on the big Technic car sets).

The minifig comes with a wrench, and with both a helmet and a wig (the helmet does NOT fit when the wig is on). There are two different sets of wheel covers for the Ferrari.

The set takes an hour or two to build, if you're not in a hurry. As always, the printed step-by-step LEGO building instructions are very clear. You can also get the building instructions onto a tablet or other mobile device by scanning a maze code (included in the printed instructions) and then following the directions to download the appropriate app.

title: Fun for Any Kid Who Loves Doll Houses, Miniatures
text:
This LEGO FRIENDS MIA'S PLAY CUBE (41403 Building Kit, New 2020 (40 Pieces)) is fun for any kid who loves doll houses and/or miniatures. When you open the assembled cube, there's a little world inside: Mia dressed as a veterinary, ready to vaccinate her little rabbit ‚Äúpatient‚Äù.

The vet's office is decorated with three stickers: a poster in the back of the right half, and a meter and a display screen with a rabbit pic in the left half. (There are bonus stickers that can be used anywhere a child likes--perhaps on the outside of the cube?) The assemblies stay solidly in place when the cube halves are closed for travel.

Something that I love about this set, is that the ‚Äúsurprise‚Äù animal for this set 41403 is always a rabbit, but a rabbit in one of four different colors. I was happy to get a gold rabbit, but was relieved that I felt no pressure to ‚Äúcollect them all‚Äù when it came to the ‚Äúsurprise‚Äù. The current play cube series sets have animal surprises as follows: birds (41400); puppies (41401); mice (41402); rabbits (this set 41403); and cats ((41404).

The furnishings in Mia's cube are easy to build, though you need to study the drawings carefully because there is NOT a separate step for each piece that is added. When you're finished, you will probably have some extra single pieces left over (e.g., a few dots, an extra syringe). However, if you have any two-stud pieces left, you' ve made a mistake and have left something out.

title: Another Great LEGO Set That Started With Idea From LEGO Fan
text:
This LEGO IDEAS 21319 CENTRAL PERK BUILDING KIT (New 2019; 1,070 Pieces) started out on the LEGO ‚ÄúIdeas‚Äù website, where LEGO fans submit their own ideas for builds. When a build receives 10,000 votes from individual LEGO fans (not as easy as you might think!), LEGO considers it for manufacture and release as a regular LEGO set, made available in retail stores and online. (To find the site for participation in ‚ÄúIdeas‚Äù voting, Google for ‚ÄúLego Ideas‚Äù.)

The Central Perk set is true to the TV show that inspired it. The familiar orange couch is there, along with the coffee shop service bar, and the stage with standing microphone. Minifigs represent Ross Geller, Rachel Green, Chandler Bing, Monica Geller, Joey Tribbiani, Phoebe Buffay, and Gunther.

The thing I love most about LEGO building sets is the way that the square and rectangular bricks transform as you build into recognizable things (e.g., the orange couch). I also find that building LEGO sets is relaxing, like assembling a jigsaw puzzle.

As always, the step-by-step LEGO building instructions are crystal clear. Do note that this Central Perk set has a LOT of small pieces (e.g., coffee cups, single- and double-stud plates, etc.). This makes it a bit fiddly to build.

title: Simplified ‚ÄúFrozen‚Äù Ice Castle Set Has Light Brick!
text:
[[VIDEOID:1c8150e87e66d2b60e0ec8095157a4f1]] If you're an adult, this LEGO DUPLO DISNEY FROZEN ICE CASTLE (10899; New 2019; 59 Pieces) takes less than half an hour to assemble, but it's a terrific set. DUPLO blocks are intended for very young builders, and are much larger than regular LEGO blocks. Thus this ‚ÄúFrozen‚Äù ice castle set lacks the detail of the regular [[ASIN:B07TB4WCJM LEGO ‚ÄúFrozen‚Äù ice palace]] (see photos). But this DUPLO set has a light brick!

The light brick is powered by 3 button cell batteries (pre-installed). When you press the button on the brick, it cycles through a series of colors for a short time, then stops automatically. By repeatedly pressing the button, you can get all white lights; or all blue, red, yellow, green, purple, orange lights. The batteries are replaceable, but you will need a small Phillips head screwdriver to open the light brick. The batteries are NOT accessible to small children.

In comparison to the regular LEGO set, the other great thing about this DUPLO set is the size of the play figures. Elsa, Anna, and Olaf are much larger than regular LEGO mini-figures, so they're more fun to play with or display. Elsa and Anna have skirts with elastic waists that go on over the plastic figures. Elsa has a sparkly cape, and Anna has a dark red cloak. Olaf is just himself!

It's kind of amazing, how much the look and feel of the LEGO ‚ÄúFrozen‚Äù ice palace set is retained in this simplified DUPLO set.

title: Excellent Unikitty Figure; Fiddly to Assemble But Stable Model
text:
This LEGO SYSTAR PARTY CREW BUILDING KIT (from THE LEGO MOVIE 2; Set 70848, New 2019, 196 Pieces) is kinda fiddly to assemble. It has a lot of pieces, but they're mostly small pieces (1 or 2 studs). Mixed in are some specialty pieces (e.g., Unikitty's cloud stole, the golden scallop shell, the piano keyboards) that require considerable creativity to be used in other projects.

As an adult Unikitty fan (don't ask me why!), I love the new Unikitty figure. She has fancy boots, and two different faces. One face has sunglasses, the other has a starry-eyed expression. Unikitty's cloud stole adds a touch of elegance.

The finished pirate figure, with all of its one-man-band instruments, stands up solidly. This is a tribute to the designer, because the arms and back have a lot of weight to support. The arms and legs can be repositioned in their ball-socket joints.

If you download the Lego Life app (available for both iOS and Android), you can scan the maze code on the front of the printed instructions and get building instructions for an ‚ÄúIntergalactic Drum Set‚Äù (see photo). This uses parts from the basic build, and extends the building fun. Scanning the maze code also provides the set's building instructions, in case you prefer to build from a tablet or cellphone display.

title: Reissue of Previously Discontinued Elsa's Ice Palace Building Set
text:
This LEGO DISNEY PRINCESS ELSA'S MAGICAL ICE PALACE 43172 TOY CASTLE BUILDING SET (New 2019; 701 Pieces) is a reissue of the previously discontinued 41148 set of the same name that was originally released in 2017 (also at a retail price of $79.99). Some of the ad pages in the 43172 building instructions are different, but the models are the same.

The Elsa's Magical Castle model isn't large, but it has loads of sparkle and detail; and tons of play potential in the many accessories (e,g., castle furniture, Olaf's train) and moving parts (e,g., swirling staircase, snow slide). It's one of my all-time favorite LEGO buildings--one that I have on permanent display (alongside my big Disney castle model).

What I love most about Elsa's castle is that it incorporates a lot of transparent ‚ÄúFrozen blue‚Äù bricks, many of which have embedded silver sparkles. I love shiny stuff, and Elsa's shimmering cape is something to behold. I also love trains, so Olaf's train is another plus. The little snowmen's teeter-totter (near the snow fort) is fun. I don't really care for the scary snow monster, but it helps in reenacting scenes from the movie.

Some of the model's sparkle is added with stickers, but there aren't a lot of stickers, and they're easy to apply. There is a moving slide that opens and closes the tall castle front doors. There is a spiral staircase that swirls open when you turn a knob. The figures of Elsa and Anna are true to the cartoon figures in the Frozen film. This is truly a great, classic LEGO set, based on a great, classic Disney movie.

title: Sphere Holds Six Different, Squishable Harry Potter Figures
text:
These BASIC FUN MASH'EMS SUPER SPHERE HARRY POTTER SERIES 1 figures are very cute, and fun to squish. My black plastic sphere contained 6 different Harry Potter characters, each one packed in its own easy-to-open plastic ‚Äúclamshell‚Äù. The clamshell keeps the characters from becoming stuck together for any reason while in transit or on warehouse or store shelves.

My secret figure turned out to be Dobby, which is one of my favorite HP characters. Everybody needs a house elf (preferably a freed one)!

The colors on the figures are very bright and clear, and look exactly like the product page photos. All together, these make an attractive small desktop or bookshelf display.

title: Beautiful Model Uses Lots of Sparkly Transparent Blue Elements
text:
One reason to like this SHIMMER & SHINE SPARKLE SPA! 70837 BUILDING KIT (from THE LEGO MOVIE 2; 691 Pieces) is that it includes a lot of the beautiful, sparkly, transparent blue elements previously seen in the LEGO ‚ÄúFrozen‚Äù kits. Another reason to like it is that it includes a rotating platform for the vampire (or another minifig), and a transparent lever for emptying the spa tub (along with Unikitty or any other hapless tub occupant).

Despite the high number of pieces (691), this is not a large model. Many of the pieces are one- or two-stud elements or specialty elements (e.g., flames) that are mostly added for architectural decoration. Still, the high piece count means that the model takes a while to build (always a good thing, in my opinion).

As always, the building instructions are easy to follow. The instructions can also be downloaded to an Apple or Android mobile device. You use the LEGO Life app to scan the QR code (looks like a maze) that is printed on the box and the instruction booklet. (The downloaded instructions are exactly the same as the printed ones.)

title: Big Kit With Lots of Play Potential
text:
This REX'S REXPLORER! 70835 BUILDING KIT (from LEGO The Movie 2; 1172 Pieces) is a big kit that takes a while to build (a good thing, in my opinion). The worst thing about it is the color choice of dark blue for the bricks. Dark blue always makes the printed building instructions hard to follow--the printed black brick outlines merge right in with the blue of the bricks unless you have strong lighting. The best thing about the kit is the little raptor figures, which have vicious-looking moveable jaws.

At times the build is repetitive, because the Rexplorer has four wheels and corners to complete (like any LEGO vehicle). I ran into one problem with the build: For the four corners beginning at Step 115, you must add the assembled piece with studs DOWN to make a solid build. I originally added the piece with the studs sideways, which didn't look quite right, and which made the area unstable later (pieces were easily dislodged with play). The correct placement isn't clear from looking at the Step 115 page (see photos). When built correctly, the Rexplorer is a robust model that holds together well.

Once built, this set has a lot of play potential. The Rexplorer has a cargo hold that opens at the side, and it's loaded with stud- and bolt-shooting weapons. The vehicle also has cockplts that open to hold raptors or minifigs. The set has Rex and Emmett minifigures with weapons, two brick-built Plantimals, and 2 raptor figures, plus a big weapon for a raptor to carry on its back.

title: Big LEGO Blocks Make Crazy Decorative Creatures
text:
As a kid, I loved the puzzle books with split pages that let you make crazy animals and people by mixing and matching the parts. So of course I love these LEGO DUPLO MY FIRST FUN PUZZLE BUILDING BLOCKS (10885; 15 Pieces). DUPLO is the line of extra-large LEGO elements that are geared to small children; this set is for ages 1¬Ω and up.

The set contains three big blocks (2¬Ω‚Äù wide x 1¬Ω‚Äù high x 1¬º‚Äù deep) for each of five different cartoon creatures (crocodile, flamingo, tiger, zebra, giraffe). The blocks can be assembled in any combination. They are printed on only one side, so you can also work with them as solid-color elements. (DUPLO blocks work exactly like standard LEGO blocks, but are easier for very young children to handle.)

The assembled 3-block creatures are highly decorative. They'll stand up by themselves on a night table, bookshelf, or dresser.

title: Heart-Shaped Treasure Box Is Display Stand for Andrea's Performances
text:
This LEGO FRIENDS ANDREA'S HEART BOX 41354 BUILDING KIT (84 Pieces) makes a sweet little (3.5" wide x 3" high) treasure box that can also be used to store the Andrea figure and her accessories. The accessories include a mic, a guitar, an ice cream cone, hair ribbons, a headphone set, a sound speaker, and a stand for displaying the heart box in an upright position.

The colorful box also doubles as a display stand for Andrea. (The fuchsia square on the box lid has a stud that holds the little doll securely.) When placed atop the box, surrounded by her accessories, Andrea is set up for a musical performance.

The heart-shaped box is quick and easy to assemble. The lid fits snugly, and there's room for a charm bracelet or a few rings.

The building kit is one of a series that features each of the LEGO Friends characters. The completed Friends treasure boxes also stack--a nice extra touch, as you would expect to see from LEGO.

title: Expert Puzzle Goes Quickly; Worth Saving to Assemble Second Time
text:
At 1000 pieces, this SPRINGBOK EIFFEL MAGIC JIGSAW PUZZLE (1000 Pieces) is definitely an ‚Äúexpert‚Äù puzzle. However, it goes together very quickly, because it has large blocks of unique colors--if you color-sort your pieces at the beginning, the jigsaw morphs into a series of much smaller jigsaws.

My puzzle, received in March 2019, had ALL of the pieces. No surprise, because I've assembled many, many Springbok jigsaws in my lifetime, and have never found one to be less than perfect. (The negative reviews suggest that Springbok temporarily had a quality control problem with this puzzle design. I sympathize with the people who received defective puzzles--even though Springbok will replace a defective puzzle, any guarantee is cold comfort when you finish a jigsaw and discover pieces missing.)

Though I wasn't crazy about the picture, I ended up loving this jigsaw, and am saving it to put together a second time. It's really fun to assemble, because the crazy-shaped pieces let you find fits by overall shapes as well as by design colors and patterns. There are very few dark or ambiguous pieces that are hard to place in a particular area of the design.

The only thing that I didn't like about the puzzle is that two pieces frequently slide together side-by-side to make holes for the tabs of other pieces. This means that when you assemble a small area (e.g., the pink automobile in the middle), you can't easily pick it up to move it to the correct location. You have to slide the assembly across your tabletop, or slide a sheet of paper under the assembly to support it as it's moved.

Note that this is a very large (30‚Äù x 24‚Äù) jigsaw. Check to make sure that it will fit on your tabletop.

title: Big, Complicated Set Is Great for Adults, Too
text:
As an Adult Fan of LEGO, I love the big, complicated sets like this LEGO IDEAS VOLTRON 121311 BUILDING KIT (2321 Pieces). The LEGO building instructions are always crystal clear, so that even the biggest sets with the most unusual building techniques are easy to assemble. All that's required is that you set out the pieces for each step, and check your model against the picture before you go on to the next step.

This big Voltron mech is made up of five smaller transformer lions, just like in the Japanese anime TV series and the later Dreamworks series. This is the absolute best kind of big LEGO set, because the many elements and parts extend the building experience as long as possible. When you're done, you have a great model to display, and when you tire of the model, you have a lot of elements available to use for other projects of your own design.

Volton comes out of the LEGO Ideas program, which means it was originally submitted to the LEGO Ideas website by a LEGO fan. After the fan model received 10,000 supporting votes from other LEGO fans, it was selected to be sold as a regular LEGO set. The Ideas sets are generally available for a limited time, so you should order Voltron fairly promptly if you love the set.

Downloadable building instructions are always available at the LEGO website--look them up by the set number (121311 for Voltron). However, the cheapest way to get all the necessary elements--and any specialized elements--is to buy a building set when it's still available from LEGO. When LEGO has a set, Amazon often has the same set at a slightly lower price.

title: Wind Turbine Set Is Much More Fun Than Advertising Suggests
text:
This LEGO CREATOR EXPERT VESTAS WIND TURBINE BUILDING KIT (10268; 826 Piece) is a fascinating set that's much more fun than the advertising makes it appear. Its best feature is also its greatest drawback--the huge turbine blades take a lot of space to display and operate. The blades are motorized (with a servo hidden in the ‚ÄúVestas‚Äù box at the top), and when they're turning, the two house entrance lights turn on. What better way to dramatize the point that a single huge wind turbine can power thousands of homes?

The model is slightly challenging to build, because it calls for a lot of studs-not-on-top assembly. It's especially interesting to see how the heavy wind turbine assemblage is secured to the base with only LEGO elements. The set does use specialized large green elements around the shaft to hide the battery box and to help hold the wind turbine firmly.

The model also demonstrates the one feature that bothers me about wind turbines as a source of electricity--they are huge, and loom over their surrounding landscape. The little house is dwarfed by the wind turbine. The house is cute, with windows and door that open, a range and sink, a lamp on a table, and a patio with a table and chairs (created from ‚Äúrepurposed‚Äù wheel-well elements).

The minifigs (two Vestas engineers, a female homeowner, and a dog) are great. The engineers have a van that holds their work bench and a hand truck loaded with service tanks and a big assortment of tools. The instruction book includes several pages describing the development of wind turbines as a power source, and showing diagrams of how they work to create electricity from wind currents.

The wind turbine on the model can be rotated by hand atop the shaft. Only the wind turbine blades are motorized. The blades are operated by a switch at the bottom of the shaft. The motor and lights run on 6 AA batteries (not included). The trees in the set are made from plants. (My LEGO Wind Turbine set was purchased from a LEGO Shop.)

title: Benny's Squad From LEGO Movie 2
text:
The LEGO Movie 2 trailer that I saw didn't include Benny, but I know that kids will enjoy re-enacting his movie scenes with this BENNY'S SPACE SQUAD BUILDING KIT (70841; 68 Pieces). (The movie is scheduled for release on February 8, 2019.)

The kit focuses on the four minifigs (Kenny, Benny, Lenny, Jenny), and a robot. The spacesuits are printed with the planet symbols (no stickers to frustrate small children). There are two vehicles (space shuttle, lander car), and some tools/weapons.

As always, the pictorial assembly instructions are simple, clear, and easy to follow. The kit, which is suitable for children ages 5 and up, has standard LEGO elements (not Duplo). There are many small pieces.

title: Building Set for Overwatch Gamers Features Tracer, Widowmaker
text:
This LEGO OVERWATCH TRACER VS. WIDOWMAKER BUILDING KIT (75970; 129 Pieces) has two great Overwatch minifigs (Tracer and Widowmaker), plus a satellite drone vehicle and a printed ‚ÄúCharge Station‚Äù base. The minifigs' bodies and heads are printed with the characters' details, and have specialized ‚Äúwigs‚Äù that make the characters immediately recognizable to Overwatch gamers.

The set has a few stickers--chiefly the gold panels on the sides of the drone. The base is printed with a Gibraltar map to pinpoint the battle location. The set has a lot of pieces, and is fun to assemble.

title: Printed Elements Include Two Different Unikitty Faces
text:
If you're a Unikitty fan (like me), you'll love this 76-piece building set. THE LEGO MOVIE 2 UNIKITTY'S SWEETEST FRIENDS EVER! Kit (70822) has two pink blocks with different Unikitty expressions. One block makes a typically wide-eyed Unikitty, the other makes her into a laughing Unikitty. My favorite thing about the Unikitty cartoon is the ever-changing Unikitty expressions, so I'm delighted to get two new ‚Äúfaces‚Äù for my collection of LEGO Unikitties.

All eyes and details on the figures (the ice cream cone, the chocolate bar, and Unikitty herself) are printed--there are no clumsy stickers to frustrate a small child. This set is designed for children 5 years of age and up. The elements are standard-sized LEGO bricks and plates (not DUPLO) that are compatible with all LEGO sets.

The pictorial instructions are simple and easy to understand. The set makes the three figures shown on the retail box, plus a charming tea cart accessory.

.

title: Preschoolers Can Build Cute DUPLO Invaders From LEGO Movie 2
text:
The LEGO MOVIE 2 trailer suggests that EMMET AND LUCY'S VISITORS FROM THE DUPLO PLANET are destructive, evil creatures, but the figures you build from this 53-piece set (10895) are awfully cute. The Duplo bricks are much larger than standard LEGO bricks, because they're designed for very young LEGO builders (ages 1¬Ω to 5).

This set is intended for children ages 2 and up, but it's fun for adults like me as well. I love the scaled-up figures of Lucy and Emmet. They arrive already assembled, but move just like regular minifigs--the heads turn, the arms move, and the legs bend to allow sitting or standing.

The elements with the invaders' single eyes are printed, so there are no clumsy stickers to add. The bricks come in bright crayon colors (red, blue, yellow, orange, green, red, purple, white). There are simple, illustrated building instructions for all of the models shown on the box.

THE LEGO MOVIE 2 is scheduled for release on February 8, 2019.

title: Building Toy Can't Be Assembled--Disappointing
text:
This THAMES & KOSMOS GIANT DINOSAUR SKELETON KIT is a child's building toy straight out of a parent's worst nightmare! IF you are able to assemble the model, the large size is the only good thing about it. There aren't many pieces; the pieces all lack detail; the front leg pieces are ridiculous, pathetic cutouts; and the skull and jaw are tricky to assemble.

Perhaps my kit was defective, but the pieces were so badly manufactured, it was NOT possible to even build the T-rex model. Only 3 of the 9 rib pieces would slide into the slots intended for them. The other 6 rib pieces were simply too big to fit into their slots. The only way to make them fit would be (1) to file down the rib pieces to narrow them, or (2) to file the slots to widen them. Prying on the slots to open them wider only met with failure.

Other joints in the model (e.g., the spine, the hips, the large legs) were hard to fit together, and took tremendous hand strength to press together and join. A young child would NOT be able to ‚Äúsnap together‚Äù these pieces at all. My dinosaur stood up--it balances on its tail when you position the legs just so--but a dinosaur without ribs is not anything you want to display.

Even the manual was disappointing. The building instructions are all right, but the accompanying ‚Äúscientific‚Äù explanations are nothing more than a collection of simplistic illustrated factoids.

As a child's gift, this building kit is bound to disappoint, and is all too likely to produce tears of frustration and unhappiness on a child's special day or holiday.

title: Huge, Fearsome Shark Makes Great Toy
text:
The shark in this AQUAMAN & WARRIOR SHARK PACK is huge, which makes it a really great toy. The shark is fearsome--the articulated tail moves from side to side and the jaws open and close when you squeeze the buttons behind the bolt-shooter. The shark even has a wheel for rolling around on the floor.

The Aquaman figure has good detail molded into the plastic, plus a golden trident and a water weapon. Both weapons are removable for more play options. I think that any Aquaman fan, yn or old, will get a kick out of this set.

title: Beautiful Action Figure With Removable Jumpsuit, Water-Blaster Weapon
text:
This beautiful AQUAMAN MERA DOLL is a good choice for a doll to be played with (not just displayed on a shelf in an unopened box). The jumpsuit, made of sparkly ‚Äúscaly‚Äù fabric, is removable, so a creative child can dress Mera in her/his own home-sewn outfits. The doll has a terrific ‚Äúwater-blaster‚Äù weapon that snaps onto her right arm.

Mera's abundant hair is an unnatural shade of bright red, which is the doll's only negative. The doll's features, based on the movie actress' features, are absolutely beautiful. The 12‚Äù doll size is very good for action-figure play.

This is an affordable action figure (about $21 on Amazon). If you're looking for a Mera doll primarily for display, you might prefer the [[ASIN:B01N4U5TD7 Barbie Mera doll]], which has a sculpted costume, but no weapon.

title: All Parts for ‚ÄúAstron‚Äú, ‚ÄúAstrobot‚Äù, or ‚ÄúRover‚Äù Models
text:
JIMU robots are somewhat challenging to build, but I like them because they're robust when completed and easy to drive (using the free iOS or Android app). This UBTECH JIMU ROBOT ASTROBOT SERIES: COSMOS KIT (387 Parts and Connectors) has the parts for three different builds: a cute dancing robot (Astron), a tractor-tread robot (Astrobot), and a tractor-wheeled robot (Rover). All three models have eyes that light up in colors.

If you want, you can build one model, take it apart, and build another. However, be warned that the components are extremely hard to take apart. The components are compatible with the components in other JIMU robot kits--if you want to create your own robots, you can combine different kits. (The JIMU components are NOT compatible with LEGO Technic elements.)

JIMU robots are controlled with Bluetooth--pairing is easy, once they're turned on or plugged into a power source. They don't have separate controllers, so you need a tablet or smartphone to work them. It's a good idea to charge the controller cubes before you start building--charging takes about an hour--so that you can play with the robot as soon as you're finished building it.

Building instructions are NOT included in the box, except for a Quickstart guide that tells you where to get the detailed instructions. You have to download the JIMU app to get the building instructions. The detailed instructions are presented in 3D--at each step you can rotate the model 360 degrees and look at it from every angle until you're sure that you've got it right.

Older kids should be able to complete these robots, and to program robot moves beyond the basic built-in moves by using the Blockly coding system. Blockly is part of the downloaded JIMU app.

title: All Parts for ‚ÄúDirtbot‚Äú or ‚ÄúDozerbot‚Äù Models
text:
I really like the JIMU robots, because they're interesting to build, robust when completed, and easy to drive (using the free iOS or Android app). This UBTECH JIMU ROBOTS BUILDERBOTS SERIES OVERDRIVE KIT (410 Parts and Connectors) has everything you need to build a dump-truck robot (Dirtbot) or a dirt-mover robot (Dozerbot). It's a great kit for people (like me) who love building models of heavy construction equipment.

If you want, you can build one model, take it apart, and build the other model. However, be warned that the components are extremely hard to take apart. The components are completely interchangeable with the components in other JIMU robot sets. (The components are NOT compatible with LEGO Technic elements.) Combining JIMU sets gives you more flexibility if you want to create your own robots.

JIMU robots are controlled with Bluetooth--pairing is easy, once they're turned on or plugged into a power source. They don't have separate controllers, so you need a tablet or smartphone to work them. It's a good idea to charge the controller cubes before you start building--charging takes about an hour--so that you can play with the robot as soon as you're finished building it.

Building instructions are NOT included in the box, except for a Quickstart guide that tells you where to get the detailed instructions. You have to download the JIMU app to get the building instructions. The detailed instructions are presented in 3D--at each step you can rotate the model 360 degrees and look at it from every angle until you're sure that you've got it right.

The JIMU robots are moderately difficult to build, but older kids should be able to complete them. Once the robots are complete, you can use the Blockly coding system to program robotic moves beyond the models' basic built-in moves. Blockly is part of the downloaded JIMU app.

title: Incredibly Fiddly Build That Works If You Follow Drawings Exactly
text:
It's possible to build this THAMES & KOSMOS GECKOBOT WALL CLIMBING ROBOT so that it will climb mirrors, but it's an incredibly fiddly build. If you decide to try it, keep these things in mind:

1. Attach the legs so that they look EXACTLY like the drawings, with the small moving connector pieces standing parallel to the tabletop. (The suction cups will be positioned without any legs lifted up.)
2. Check your assembly with the legs attached to make sure that the legs move easily. (Don't push the gears too tightly against the body pieces.)
3. Make sure that the motor piece is attached with the orange circular part starting in neutral position (per the drawing).
4. Position the red ‚Äúpointer‚Äù cams with one pointing straight up and one pointing straight down when the legs are positioned as in (1) above.
5. Position the two stacked red ‚Äúcircles‚Äù (the pieces that hold the short axle on top) so that the two little extensions are pointing in opposite directions.
6. Position the top axle with the ‚Äúx‚Äù in the position shown in the drawing.
7. Attach the hoses so that the tops of the legs don't contact or catch on the hose loops when the model walks.

My Geckobot walked smoothly across the tabletop, and stuck to a mirror, but walked only a few steps before it would slide down the mirror. When I tried to follow the instructions for fixing this, the model came apart in places, so that a rebuild was needed. (You really MUST build the model exactly according to the drawings.) At that point, I put the project aside to fix at a later date.

A problem with this model is that some of the connector parts are easily dislodged. Another problem is that two AAA batteries don't seem to supply as much power as is really needed to drive this fairly heavy model. My alkaline batteries actually heated up with the effort, and they couldn't drive the model if there was any drag on the moving parts.

The batteries were NOT quickly drained with the effort. Every time the ‚Äúon‚Äù switch seemed not to be working, I removed the batteries and tested them. They still were good, and they were still able to power the model after I made adjustments that eliminated drag.

Kids will find this model frustrating, unless they really enjoy tinkering with something for as long as it takes to make it work. I spent an extra 2-3 hours beyond what it takes for the build, just repositioning the cams and fixing the legs for smooth operation.

title: Extremely Difficult If Approached in Conventional Manner
text:
This BGRAAMIENS 1000-PIECE JIGSAW PUZZLE (‚ÄúBlooming Color‚Äù; Challenge Blue Board Round Jigsaw Puzzle) is extremely difficult if you approach it in the conventional way--by (1) laying out the pieces face up, (2) assembling the border first, and (3) filling in the puzzle by referring to the picture on the box. The irregularly shaped pieces, the use of colors in small areas across the entire puzzle, and the confusing curved lines in the design add greatly to the difficulty.

Fortunately, this puzzle has letters printed on the back that make the puzzle easier to assemble. If you sort the pieces by A, B, C, etc., you will have a much more manageable puzzle. It's still quite difficult, but the assembly will be entertaining and enjoyable, rather than a Herculean labor. (See my photos of the 54 pieces that are marked with ‚ÄúA‚Äù, to see how difficult the puzzle really is.)

The puzzle pieces are not as nice as the ones in Ravensburger puzzles, but they're made of fairly heavy cardboard, and they fit together precisely. When you find the correct piece, you know that it's the right one.

title: Fabulous Set of 100 Colors, Plus 12 Special Effects Colors (Metallics, Neons)
text:
This Amazon Exclusive CRAYOLA COLORED PENCIL BUNDLE (100 Crayola Colored Pencils, plus 12 Art With Edge FX Colored Pencils) is a fabulous set. The big box has 100 different standard colors (no repeats), and the smaller box has 12 different metallic and neon colors (no repeats).

The big box of 100 colors gives you everything you need to create beautifully shaded pencil drawings. The silver and gold metallics really shine like metal, and the colorful metallics lay down color with sparkly flecks. The neons simply jump off the page.

The pencil leads are fairly soft, and are very comfortable to draw or color with.

title: Fun Model-Building Kit Painlessly Teaches Concepts of Physics, Engineering
text:
This THAMES & KOSMOS THE BIG ENGINEERING MAKERSPACE SCIENCE EXPERIMENT KIT is the real deal--a fun model-building kit that painlessly teaches basic concepts of physics (e.g., thermal air currents, levers, momentum). Each model (e.g., crane, helicopter) actually works, and is accompanied by a ‚Äúwhat's happening here‚Äù explanation in the manual of why it works (e.g., turning a crank hoists a crane load by exerting force on a rope threaded through pulleys that share the weight to be lifted; a helicopter's fast tail rotor produces a force that counteracts the main rotor's force to stabilize the helicopter).

The models are assembled from plastic parts (some parts are similar to LEGO Technic elements) by following clear step-by-step diagrams (similar to LEGO building instructions). They are powered by a pressurized air tank controlled by a switch with a lever. There are no batteries to buy or charge, because you pressurize the air tank by pumping air into it (the pump assembly resembles a bicycle tire pump).

Each model has suggestions for finding out more about the scientific principles that relate to it. The manual indicates the difficulty level of each model with a three-dot system (easy, medium, difficult).

This kit may seem expensive (about $90 on Amazon), but it teaches a LOT about the practical application of physical and engineering principles, for the price of a single medium-sized LEGO Technic kit. It's a kit to use in home schooling, or to give to a child who really wants to understand why and how construction equipment, vehicles, watercraft, aircraft, and cameras work in the real world.

title: Favorite Character From Old Harry Potter LEGO Set
text: Dobby has always been one of my favorite characters from the Harry Potter books.  This LEGO HARRY POTTER DOBBY MINIFIGURE WITH SOCK--a minifigure from one of the older LEGO Harry Potter sets--depicts Dobby exactly as I imagine him.  The shapeless, dirty shift and the sock are printed graphics (not stickers).

title: Advertises 10+ Rolling Ideas, But Has Actual Pieces for Only 8 Ideas
text:
This MEGA CONSTRUX INVENTIONS WHEELS PACK contains all the pieces you need to build any 1 of the 8 models shown on the package front: glasses launcher, red tractor, mini camera, fire truck, blue dragster, stretchable semi, yellow go-cart, and yellow rover robot. However, the bag contains building instructions for only 2 models: glasses launcher and red tractor.

For the rest of the building instructions, you need the free app, which requires an Android or iOS tablet (not a smartphone). The package promises 10 rolling models, but the motorcycle and speedboat each require purchase of an additional building set (FWP20 and FWP28, respectively).

Of course Mega Construx has an online ‚Äúcommunity‚Äù that kids can join. After joining, kids can ‚Äúearn badges, connect with other fans, and more!‚Äù At least it isn't necessary to join up in order to get the building instructions. A nice thing about the app is that you can click on a picture of a model you like, and see exactly which building kits you need to buy to have all the pieces.

The Mega Construx pieces are compatible with my LEGO pieces, though they are made of a different plastic material. I think that Mega Construx pieces are harder to build with; also, they mostly press together without actually clicking together. The building instructions aren't as clear as the ones in LEGO sets, and I don't like the Mega Construx models nearly as well as the LEGO models for similar vehicles.

The glasses launcher strikes me as unusually weird. Why would you want to build something that hooks over an earpiece, has a pseudo-sight in front of your glasses lens, and fires tiny little bolts?

title: ‚ÄúTalkative‚Äù Grabberbot Is Easy to Drive, Responsive; Somewhat Difficult to Build
text:
This UBTECH JIMU ROBOT-BUILDERBOTS KIT (Interactive Building Block System (357 Piece)) is so beautifully packaged, you'd almost think it was a smartphone or an Apple product. It comes in a heavy-duty, magnetic-closure box that opens like a book. Inside, the main controller, connectors and fasteners are packed in colorful paper boxes that nest perfectly in the big outer box. Is such a lovely unboxing experience wasted on a kid's toy?

This kit will make either a ‚ÄúGrabberbot‚Äù or a ‚ÄúDigbot‚Äù. I say ‚Äúeither‚Äù, because the building components are extremely hard to take apart--you are NOT going to want to try a rebuild of either completed robot. Some (but not all) of the components are similar to LEGO Technic elements, but they're smaller and definitely NOT compatible with LEGO.

In an afternoon (about 4 hours), I built the Grabberbot, which I like a lot. Using the Jimu app (iOS or Android), it's easy to drive, very responsive, and actually picks things up. Grabberbot has a cool, multicolored LED light (you can program custom colors), and he has a voice cube with a large repertoire of sounds (also programmable).

Grabberbot is controlled with Bluetooth--pairing is easy, once he's turned on or plugged into a power source. He does NOT have a separate controller, so you must have a tablet or a smartphone to make him work. (I use an iPad Mini.) It's a good idea to charge the controller cube before you start building--it takes an hour or so. You do NOT want to spend an afternoon building a robot, and then have to wait for the battery to charge before you can play with it!

You can't build the Grabberbot without a tablet or smartphone--you have to download the app to get the building instructions. (This is a pet peeve of mine; I believe that the instructions for building toys belong in the box.) However, in defense of the download-only instructions, they are presented in 3D! If you're unsure about a particular step, you can rotate the model 360 degrees and look at it from every angle until you're sure that you've got it right.

Grabberbot is more difficult to build than a motorized LEGO set. There are three reasons for this: (1) the instructions don't always show the elements recognizably or exactly the way they go together (e.g., the sensor box has fewer connector holes than the one shown in the instructions); (2) the instructions don't always start at the easiest place for the next step in the assembly; and (3) the components click together so firmly, you need pliers to separate some of them if you make a mistake.

Sadly, the color-changing LED light needs to be programmed if you want it to do more than flash colored lights for a few seconds when Grabberbot is first turned on. I did very little with the programming portion of the app, which requires you to identify which of the four servo motors you want to give instructions to (they are numbered), to choose commands for the motor(s), and to name and record the resulting
action. Programming doesn't seem to be hard, but it does take some study and practice.

There is a charger with an AC adapter included. The red light on the controller box changes to green when the battery is fully charged. A firmware update starts automatically when you first connect the Grabberbot; it takes only a few minutes.

title: Fun Set Builds Laboratory of Unikitty's Resident Mad Scientist
text:
The LEGO UNIKITTY DR. FOX LABORATORY BUILDING KIT (359 Piece) is an inexpensive LEGO set (about $27 on Amazon) that has a lot of play potential. With 359 pieces, it takes a while to build the laboratory of Unikitty's resident mad scientist (Dr. Fox), and there are many interesting features (e.g., the little ‚Äúrefrigerator‚Äù with the transparent door, and its contents).

Taking center stage is the ‚Äúsparkle matter‚Äù scanner from the second episode in the Unikitty cartoon series. It's at the left side, and next to it is a little set of white rollers that make a conveyor belt for jars filled with sparkle matter. At the far right is a turntable for filled sample jars that moves when you push it.

The building techniques are easy, and the instructions are clear, so young children should be able to assemble the set. There are a couple of stickers (Dr. Fox's blackboard, and her instrument panel) that will probably need adult assistance in applying. The faces of the figures are printed on the bricks (no stickers required).

The laboratory has a two big clamps that can hold a figure, an examination table (ditto), and various mysterious lamps and instruments. The set includes Princess Unikitty, Prince Puppycorn, Dr. Fox, Richard, and a robot helper. This Unikitty building set is a lot of fun (especially for an adult Unikitty fan like me).

title: Tatooine Garbage/Trash Truck for Serious ‚ÄúStar Wars‚Äù Fans
text:
The LEGO STAR WARS SANDCRAWLER BUILDING KIT (1239 Piece) is a kit for serious ‚ÄúStar Wars‚Äù fans, because it's basically a Tatooine garbage/trash truck. There's not a whole lot of action surrounding a Jawa sandcrawler, but the LEGO model makes up for this by including many hinged and sliding panels that open up the interior to show Jawas and their salvaged droids and space junk inside.

This set doesn't have a huge number of pieces (1239), and the finished model isn't particularly large (12‚Äù long, 7‚Äù high, 4‚Äù wide). However, like all LEGO sets, it's interesting and fun to build. My favorite part is the chains on the four tractor wheels--the elements are sort of fiddly to connect up, but the finished tractor chains are convincingly realistic.

There are some Technic elements included to make the tractor wheels work, and to make it possible to steer the sandcrawler with an external gear wheel at the front. Minifigs included are young Luke Skywalker, 2 Jawas, an RA-7 droid, an R5-A2 astromech droid, and a medical droid.

If you want some shooting action, this set pairs nicely with the [[ASIN:B075SCRBQ6 Tatooine Battle Pack]].

title: Beautiful Diesel Engine; Batteries NOT Included
text:
This LIONEL SANTA FE DIESEL READY TO PLAY TRAIN SET (35 Piece) isn't quite ‚Äúready to play‚Äù--batteries are NOT included. You will need three (3) AAA batteries (for the controller), and six (6) C cell batteries (for the engine). Once the batteries are installed, you only need to set up the track (not electrified), and you'll have a fully operational model train.

I love the diesel engine in this set, which reproduces the engine of the iconic ‚ÄúSanta Fe Super Chief‚Äù (the flagship of the old Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway). I hate the windows of the coach and observation cars. The windows are yellow, and some have old-fashioned, 1950s-style silhouettes that are supposed to be people inside the train. (The windows are exactly the same on both sides of the cars.)

I don't know what Lionel was thinking--this set would be so much nicer without those ugly, distracting silhouettes. It would also be nicer if there were a pullman car, since the train was famous for those.

The train has the usual features of the battery-operated Lionel trains. There is a working headlight, a train horn, and a bell. The controller is paired with the engine using Bluetooth, but you don't need to download anything to operate the train.

title: Lots of Figures to Build; Room in Box to Store Other Unikitty Sets
text:
The charming Unikitty cartoon series made me a Unikitty fan, because it always makes me laugh. I like this UNIKITTY UNIKINGDOM CREATIVE BRICK BOX BUILDING KIT (433 Piece) very much. It provides the elements for building many of the series characters (Unikitty, Puppycorn, Richard, Master Frown, Square Bear, Feebee, etc.), plus a Unikitty castle, and lots of scenery.

Hawkodile and Dr. Fox are NOT included, but they're available in other sets (see [[ASIN:B078W9N8LV Party Time]], [[ASIN:B07BMH5L8B Dr. Fox's Laboratory]]). The set is packed in a big, white LEGO storage box; the box is NOT completely full of bricks, but this means there is room to store other Unikitty sets if you purchase them.

The bricks for the figures' heads are printed with their faces--small children won't need to apply stickers. The set has three building instruction booklets with pieces in corresponding numbered bags. (The presorted, numbered bags of pieces are standard with larger LEGO sets.)

The many small building projects are great for very young children. The building techniques are all basic, simple ones. The elements in the set are all standard LEGO elements (they're NOT Duplo bricks), so they're compatible with other LEGO sets you may already own.

title: Challenging Despite Small Size; Very Decorative Model
text:
The small size of this LEGO ARCHITECTURE GREAT WALL OF CHINA BUILDING KIT (551 Piece) is deceptive--it's more challenging to build than you might think, and it includes some very interesting building techniques. I'm totally awed by the clever way that the wall is chained together and secured, so that it meanders up and along the grassy ridge.

The kit took me about 2¬º hours to build, working steadily but taking time to read the factoids in the building instructions as I went along. How interesting to learn that ‚Äústicky rice‚Äù used in the mortar contributed to the wall's longevity! (Because this kit is part of the LEGO Architecture series, the instruction booklet has extras such as photos of the actual monument, a few pages of history, and some structural schematics.)

The kit includes a large quantity of beautiful dark green bricks (hunter green) that make me want to think of something else to make with them--or with that color, if I don't ever want to disassemble the model. I'm keeping the model for now, because it is very decorative when complete. (A nice feature is that there are two different ‚ÄúGreat Wall of China‚Äù ID plates--one in English, one in Chinese.)

title: Easy-to-Assemble Set With Spinning Propeller, Sparkle Matter Guns
text:
This LEGO UNIKITTY CLOUD CAR BUILDING KIT (126 Piece) is a small kit that an adult can assemble in half an hour; the building techniques are simple and straightforward, so that small children shouldn't find it difficult.

There are two elements that I particularly like, both on Unikitty's cloud car--a propeller that spins with a flick of the finger, and a pair of spring-loaded ‚Äúsparkle matter‚Äù guns that fire dots when you press the catch on the special LEGO gun element. I also like the use of a blue crystal element that becomes a fountain in a tiny park.

The figures have their faces printed on special bricks (no stickers). Unikitty has a wide, open-mouthed grin; her head turns, and she fits in a space in the cloud car. Other figures are Square Bear and Feebee.

Princess Unikitty was introduced in ‚ÄúThe LEGO Movie‚Äù. At first I thought that a hybrid unicorn/cat was creepy, but now I'm totally charmed by the ‚ÄúUnikitty‚Äù TV series that airs on the Cartoon Channel, and by the LEGO Unikitty sets. I only wish that the Unikitty minifigs with different versions of Unikitty (see [[ASIN:B07BMF3K48 Unikitty Add-On Item]] were marketed as a straightforward collection, instead of as expensive grab-bag ‚Äúmystery figures‚Äù.

title: Versatile, Fast Robot Is Somewhat Challenging to Build
text:
This UBTECH JIMU ROBOT TANKBOT (Robot TankBot App-Enabled STEM Learning Kit (190 pcs)) makes a wonderful gift, because it's so beautifully packaged. It comes in a heavy-duty, magnetic-closure box that opens like a book. Inside, the main controller, connectors and fasteners are packed in colorful paper boxes that nest perfectly in the big outer box. The unboxing experience is beautifully presented--it reminds me of unboxing an Apple product.

The Tankbot is a very cute, sturdy little robot. He's fast and responsive, and moves extremely well on his plastic tank treads. He's controlled with an app (iOS or Android), using Bluetooth. For me, pairing was almost instantaneous (once Tankbot was plugged into a power source). He does NOT have a separate controller, so you must have a tablet or a smartphone to make him work. (I use an iPad.)

You can't even build him without a tablet or smartphone--you have to download the app and the building instructions. This is a pet peeve of mine; I believe that the instructions for building toys belong in the box. However, Ubtech should perhaps be forgiven, because the building instructions are written in something that resembles Autocad. If you're unsure about a connection in a particular step, you can rotate the model 360 degrees and look at it from every angle until you're sure that you've got it right.

That said, Tankbot is something of a bear to build--much harder than the most difficult motorized LEGO sets. There are three reasons for this: (1) the instructions don't always show the elements recognizably or exactly the way they go together (e.g., the wires have a colored band that is on the wrong side in many drawings); (2) the instructions don't always start at the easiest place for the next step in the assembly; and (3) the components click together so firmly, you need pliers to separate some of them if you make a mistake.

But the struggle is probably worthwhile, because you end up with a solid, programmable robot that you can drive around, use to pick up things, and spin in celebration (just like ‚ÄúBattlebots‚Äù). Tankbot does take some practice at driving--I'm still learning the controls, but I'm not great at handling remote control toys in the first place. I haven't tried the programming portion of the app yet--even the simple programming is something you have to learn--but I have no reason to think it won't work.

Note that Tankbot's battery needs charging before you can do anything with him (including connecting to the controller app via Bluetooth). There is a charger with an AC adapter included, and Tankbot charges fairly fast. He does a firmware update automatically when you first connect him, if an update is available.

title: Charming Unikitty Kit Makes You Smile
text:
Generally I prefer LEGO building kits that aren't targeted for girls, but Unikitty is so cute, I love the cartoon and this charming kit. The LEGO UNIKITTY PARTY TIME BUILDING KIT (214 Piece) takes less than an hour for an adult to build, but has some interesting building techniques for young children. For example, the boxes for the two birthday gifts are constructed from slightly different LEGO elements--teaching that there can be more than one way to build something.

I particularly like the Hawkodile figure, which has a specialized brick for the head with a protruding yellow hawk's bill. The faces for Unikitty, Puppycorn, and Master Frown are printed on the specialized bricks for their heads. The heads on all but Master frown can be turned for play.

The birthday cake is on a trolley with wheels (like roller skates). The round plate in front spins in a full circle to imitate a dance floor, and will hold one figure at a time. The only possible negative about this set is that there are four stickers (gift box bows and ‚ÄúParty Time‚Äù) that small children will need adult help with.

My kit had quite a few extra small pieces. Perhaps these are included to simulate sparkle. The kit will make you smile.

title: Many LED Cube Projects; All Cubes Combine With LEGO Elements
text:
This CIRCUIT CUBES BRIGHT LIGHTS STEM LEARNING TOY KIT (Multicolor) has a lot of good features. It has three circuit cubes (battery, motor, LED) that can be arranged in different ways. The LED cube is the star of the kit, but it's worth having for lighting up LEGO builds that go way beyond the projects explained in the kit booklet. All of the cubes connect with LEGO studs.

Unlike many toy kits advertised as educational STEM kits, this kit has the building instructions packed inside the box. There's no need to go online and join a club (and get your personal info entered into a database) to get the instructions, although there is a Circuit Cube Club available if a child is interested.

The booklet with the projects is very clear and easy to follow. The projects include flashlight; hand-crank flashlight; telescope flashlight; gobo; lighthouse; night light; spinning light car; desk lamp; shadow puppets; and motorized gobo.

The kit has lots of different things for a child to try. It isn't a kit that takes 5 minutes to assemble, 5 minutes to see what the build does, and 5 minutes to tire of it and set it aside never to be played with again. The kit includes a small drawstring bag that is great for keeping the cubes and other parts together once the kit is unpacked.

The one thing that I didn't like about the kit is that the booklet doesn't explain anything about how circuits work. Whatever the child learns is going to come from trial-and-error experimentation with arranging the cubes. I still don't know why my original connections for the hand-crank flashlight didn't work, except for the observation that they crossed to opposite posts instead of going in a straight daisy chain sequence.

Something to watch out for if you're buying more than one of this series of kits is that you'll get the same three basic circuit cubes in some or all of them.

title: Why So Expensive?  Why Doesn't Tube Have Printed Design?
text:
This LITTLEBITS BUBBLE BOT STARTER KIT (9 Piece) has everything you need to make a cute electric bubble-blower, but why is it so expensive? (The kit is about $40 on Amazon.) And at that price, why aren't the simple instructions included in a printed leaflet inside the box? And at that price, why isn't the solid purple tube printed with the dragon/tiger/shark design shown on the packaging and in the advertising?

I was able to produce basketball-sized bubbles, using dish detergent mixed with a small amount of water. The instructions don't include a recipe for the bubble solution, so you have to experiment to get a soap bubble mixture that works. The bot works best if you put the solution into a bowl (so you can pull the tube out freely). To blow big bubbles, you need to speed up the fan gradually, using the dimmer slider.

Assembling the bot is a snap. You line up the circuit parts according to the photo in the instructions, and they click together because they're magnetized. If they're lined up wrong, the magnetic poles will force them apart, so you know you must reverse one of the circuit parts. An 8-year-old child can surely assemble this kit.

However, I don't see how this kit teaches much of anything beyond clicking magnets together and flipping switches. The instructions don't say anything about the physics principles involved. Also, it was a big disappointment to find that the tube needs to be decorated by the kit buyer. That might be okay if a stencil or template for the design shown in the ads were included, but there's nothing beyond the picture on the package.

The printable assembly instructions that you get from the littleBits web site include a link to another bubble bot that you can build from LEGO bricks and some of the parts from this kit. However, the LEGO bot requires a littleBits light sensor part, and this doesn't appear to be available for purchase except as part of an expensive set of littleBits components. Too bad, as that bubble bot is more interesting than this one.

UPDATE 08-06-18: The pdf version of the assembly instructions (if you can find them--try Googling "littleBits bubble bot instructions") has more STEM teaching information than the web site instructions that I used. The pdf explains why the circuit components need to be assembled in a certain order, and shows photos of real-life devices that use the same types of components as the components in the kit. Why these instructions are NOT included in the kit is a mystery to me.

title: Instruction Manual Is Available Online Only; Plaster of Paris Creates Mess
text:
UPDATE 08-04-2018: My mistake re the leaflet link for the instructions--the ending after the dot is "co", not "com", so the link as printed does exist. It doesn't change my star rating, though. An adult or child still must create a profile on the kit manufacturer's site to be able to view the "thirsty plant" instructions. In a high-priced kit (about $34 on Amazon), the instructions belong in the box.
-----
The first strike against this TECH WILL SAVE US THIRSTY PLANT KIT (Educational STEM Toy, Ages 8 and Up) is that there is NO instruction manual packed in the box. The second strike is that the printed leaflet actually included in the box gives a web address for obtaining the manual that no longer exists. (The company domain is available for purchase, as if the company were out of business.) The third strike is that once you locate the online manual, the thirsty plant kit requires you to cast a columnar sensor from plaster of Paris (what a mess!), but doesn't include a stirrer or the soft clay needed to close the bottom of the mold during casting.

If you want the instruction manual, you can Google ‚Äútech will save us thirsty plant kit‚Äù. It appears that the PDF version of the manual no longer exists. (At least my browser wouldn't open the pdf file from the link that Google brought up.) However, there is an online instruction manual available (as of 08-04-2018) if your child--with adult permission--signs up for a free membership in the kit maker's ‚ÄúClub Make‚Äù.

The third strike is a little unfair of me, in that the product page listing mentions the use of plaster of Paris. However, if you haven't made anything with plaster of Paris in years, you will end up with a horrible mess on your work table. It doesn't help that the instruction manual says to pour ‚Äúa thumb‚Äù of water into the included dish for mixing, when you actually need about ¬º of that (or about ¬Ω of the amount shown in the photo). I guess the manual means a child's ‚Äúthumb‚Äù.

If you succeed in making the water sensor--which needs to dry for 24 hours before you can continue assembling the kit--then putting together the circuitry seems fairly simple. I do wonder whether an 8-year-old can do it without adult help, though.

As far as I can tell, the completed water sensor will work as advertised, and flash a LED light (in the daytime only) when a potted plant's soil dries out. Unfortunately, I can't say for sure that the sensor works, because I bombed out at the sensor-casting stage.

title: Mesmerizing Toy--Hard Even for Adult to Put Down
text:
This WOWWEE STEALTH (GREEN) UNTAMED RAPTOR (Collectible Dinosaur by Fingerlings-Interactive) is just the cutest toy! It's extremely hard to put down, even for an adult like myself. It roars when poked, it purrs when stroked, it blinks its eyes, it goes to sleep in your hand. It even delivers ‚Äúdino gas‚Äù when you press and hold the nose and back of the head.

Mine works perfectly out of the box, and is mesmerizing. With a little practice, I was able to get consistent responses from my little guy (e.g., tapping 1, 2, or 3 times on the nose would consistently produce the same sounds and behavior, depending on the number of taps). The easiest actions are the transition from untamed to tamed (stroke from nose to back of head) and tamed to untamed (press and hold back of head).

I can well believe that a child would be very, very disappointed if the raptor suddenly stopped working, so parents should be prepared for this possibility. If yours should stop working, even if the batteries are good, be sure to contact the manufacturer--the web address is in the instructions.

title: Fun for Lovers of Drawbridges, Motorized Models
text:
This HOT WHEELS TRACK BUILDER STUNT BRIDGE KIT is fun for lovers of drawbridges and motorized models (like myself). The main drawback is that it takes up so much floor space. If you already have a Hot Wheels Track Builder layout, you can connect this stunt--nice because the escape from the stunt is an upward-pointing launch ramp.

There are clear instructions for assembly. If you follow them carefully, the stunt will perform as promised. Despite the dual-car launcher, this kit comes with only one car. Fortunately, Hot Wheels cars are fairly cheap, but I cannot understand why the bigger, more complicated Hot Wheels sets are always released with only one car.

The set requires two D-cell batteries, which are NOT included. This kit is NOT a good choice for Hot Wheels newbies, even though it's attractive and fun. You get the most bang for your buck with the starter kits like the [[ASIN:B01JMYP9OQ Hot Wheels Track Builder Stunt Box]]. You can add all sorts of track builder stunts to the basic set later, and choose the stunts to fit your available floor space.

title: Rocket Launcher Stunt Has Three-Stage Play Experience
text:
The novel thing about this HOT WHEELS TRACK BUILDER ROCKET LAUNCH CHALLENGE PLAYSET is the three-stage play experience. You launch a car through the loop arrangement to hit the rocket and collapse the loop; then you launch a car to jump the gap and raise the liftoff ramp; and finally you launch a car to launch the rocket.

The Stunt set has clear instructions for assembly, and if you follow them carefully, the stunt works exactly as promised. The stunt is fun by itself, but also connects to the track in your existing Hot Wheels layout, if you have one.

The stunt uses standard Hot Wheels cars. It comes with only one car, but it's best with three cars, so that you don't have to retrieve the car after each stage of play.

title: Brightly-Colored Toy Has Mix-and-Match Animals
text:
This LEARNING RESOURCES BUILD & SPIN: FARM FRIENDS (17 Pieces) toy is simply adorable. It's well-made, with big plastic pieces (no sharp edges). The gear pieces fit into holes in the base; and when assembled, they turn when the handle (the farmhouse) is turned.

The animal pieces fit atop the gears, and are totally mix-and-match. There are many, many ways to build up this set, combining different animals with different colored gears. I can't imagine a very young child's NOT having fun with this brightly-colored, cartoon-animal toy.

title: Beautiful Wooden Counting Frame for ‚ÄúRekenrek Math‚Äù Class
text:
This ETA HAND2MIND 20-BEAD REKENREK (with Activity Guide) is a solid, beautifully made wood-and-metal counting frame. The beads feel nice, and slide easily. The frame is accompanied by a teaching manual that includes lessons, number ‚Äúcards‚Äù to be cut out and mounted on heavier stock, and student problem worksheets for duplication.

The Rekenrek is intended to help students visualize numbers. I found the lessons hard to follow at first‚Äîan important element is understanding that the starting ‚ÄúHome‚Äù position is with all the beads on the right. If taught correctly, I can see how the Rekenrek would make early math classes (K-2) more tactile and fun.

The Rekenrek isn't expensive (about $15 on Amazon), considering how well-made it is. However, it will cost a fair amount to equip a class for ‚ÄúRekenrek math‚Äù. One Rekenrek is required for each student, and one for the teacher.

title: Cute Life-Size (?) BB-8 Is Space Hog
text:
This life-size (?) STAR WARS HERO DROID BB-8 is a really cute toy, but it isn't that much fun to play with. All it does is roll around (with lights and sound effects). It's nice that you can steer it with a handheld remote, or with voice commands, or even set it to follow behind you (as you wear the remote). But for me, that gets old very fast.

This toy also requires a lot of storage space. The lower ball is bigger than a basketball (more the size of a small floor exercise ball). The overall height is something like 18‚Äù. It's also rather heavy (more than 10 lbs.). Both the head and the body require charging, which is kind of a pain.

The Hero Droid BB-8 is very realistic, and mimics the movie experience. However, it's a space hog, and I think that a smaller, table-sized BB-8 is more fun.

title: Unusual Elastigirl Minifig Stars in Rooftop Pursuit Set
text:
This LEGO JUNIORS ELASTIGIRL'S ROOFTOP PURSUIT BUILDING KIT (10759; 95 Piece) features minifigs (Elastigirl and Screenslaver) from the ‚ÄúIncredibles 2‚Äù movie. Elastigirl is interesting to minfig lovers, because her body element is molded with long tubes (solid plastic) for arms, instead of having the standard poseable arms.

The set has reasonable play potential, with a helicopter and a motorcycle (the Elasticycle) for zooming around. Both vehicles have space to accommodate a minifig operator. A cute graphic element is the hypno-disc on the helicopter's propeller. The brick-built scenery (billboard, satellite dish, antenna, and helipad) inspires the acting out of many different creative stories.

LEGO Juniors building kits use standard LEGO pieces, but have slightly simplified building instructions with extra illustrated steps. The kits also use fewer brick-built components (e.g., a baseplate may come with two levels molded in), and have printed graphics rather than tricky-to-apply stickers. The bricks may come in more colors, to aid in assembly.

title: Fun-to-Play-With Model of Millennium Falcon From May 2018 ‚ÄúSolo‚Äù Movie
text:
This LEGO STAR WARS KESSEL RUN MILLENIUM FALCON BUILDING KIT (75212; 1414 pieces) is a great set‚Äîdefinitely one of my all-time favorites. When completed, the kit produces a large, heavy but solid, fun-to-play-with model of the ‚ÄúKessel Run‚Äù Millennium Falcon that's featured in the new Han Solo movie (‚ÄúSolo: A Star Wars Story‚Äù, released on 5/24/2018). As an adult, I really love this Millennium Falcon, which has a large removable space shuttle in front that accommodates a minifigure, and two powerful, spring-loaded bolt shooters. The bolts always fly 18‚Äù or more (you get four bolts). There is also a gunnery pod for minifigures in the center circular area.

The build is fairly demanding, which makes it a lot of fun for experienced builders. The parts you assemble aren't always symmetrical, and there are a lot of left- and right-handed components, so you have to pay attention to the instructions as you build. There are some ‚Äústuds not on top‚Äù segments, and some components (like the removable transparent nose cone) that are attached ‚Äúsideways‚Äù to vertical studs. There are also a few items (e.g., the lever-action doors at the top front) that attach with Technic parts.

Most of the ‚Äútriangular‚Äù pieces on the top of the model swing up for easy access to the furnished interior. Inside there are chairs that accommodate minifigures, control panels (done with stickers), coffee bars, and engine parts storage boxes. The stickers aren't excessive, and are easy to position. (I use a thin, flat, metal spudger to pick up and place the stickers accurately.)

The set has several specialized bricks that I haven't seen before (e.g., the bricks that form a channel for the space shuttle to slide in and out of the front of the model). It also has some unusual building techniques that are used to link together pieces that are installed along a curved line.
