The model has four sturdy feet, which allow it to stand on a flat surface with space for the underbody gun turret.

The set has only 1414 pieces, but many pieces are very large (e.g., the triangles that open on top). The finished model is a big, substantial toy (the circle is 12‚Äù across).

title: Book Aimed at Young Movie-Makers Really Hits the Mark
text:
LEGO MAKE YOUR OWN MOVIE (by the editors of KLUTZ) is a how-to guide for stop-motion-movie-making, using LEGO minifigures and bricks. It's aimed at young children, and it really hits the mark. I think that any child who is able to read the simple instructions should be able to make his/her own LEGO movies, and that even younger children can make stop-motion movies with adult help.

The book includes LEGO parts, background scenery, and basic scripts to get the reader started with a few simple movies, using animation apps that are loaded with cell phone cameras or that are readily available online as free downloads. My favorite feature of the book is the deck of ‚Äúscene cards‚Äù that can be removed and photographed in sequence to test the performance of the reader's chosen animation software.

If you perform this ‚Äúscene card‚Äù test, you will master the basic photography skills needed, before you invest a lot of time setting up your stop-motion frames with actual LEGO pieces. This book isn't just for kids, either‚Äîit's a great starter book for anyone who's interested in learning how to create his/her own LEGO movies.

title: Challenger Jigsaw With Beautiful Photo Is Tedious to Assemble
text:
I love the photograph for this RAVENSBURGER LE MONT-SAINT-MICHEL JIGSAW PUZZLE (1000 Piece), and I love expert challenger jigsaws, but this is the most tedious challenger puzzle that I've ever tackled. The center portion with the monastery buildings and their reflection goes very quickly, but the four outer corners are a total slog.

At least half the puzzle is pale blue or white sky/sea. There is little in the way of color differentiation, so the only way to put the pieces together is to eyeball the shapes. You can speed this up a little by sorting the blue/white pieces (e.g., 2-tabs, 3-tabs, 1-tab with squarish ‚Äúfoot‚Äù, etc.). But it will still take a long time, and close study of individual pieces, for even an expert jigsaw assembler to complete the picture.

Like all Ravensburger puzzles, this one is high quality, with 1000 totally unique pieces. The pieces click together smoothly, so you always know immediately when you've located the correct piece.

This very difficult puzzle will teach you a lot about the pattern Ravensburger follows in cutting its jigsaws. If you love jigsaw puzzles for the pure challenge, this is the puzzle for you!

title: ‚ÄúBurst Evolution‚Äù Tops Have Interchangeable Parts for Customization
text:
This BEYBLADE BURST EVOLUTION SWITCHSTRIKE STARTER PACK (Genesis Valtryek V) contains a Genesis Valtryek V (a right-spin top), and a launcher that can be used for either left-spin or right-spin tops. You will need to purchase a ‚Äúbattle stadium‚Äù separately (e.g., [[ASIN:B01F6VS3ZG Beyblade Burst Beystadium]]).

The parts for Burst Evolution tops can be interchanged to create custom tops with different strengths and weaknesses. I would strongly advise any adult who is purchasing one of these tops for a youngster to find out exactly which model it is that the kid wants. The tops perform very differently, depending on their weight and on features such as the type of tip (e.g., rollerball). The back of the toy card gives details on the features (e.g., type (attack or defense), weight, endurance, etc.) of the included top.

Hasbro's battling tops are fun toys, but they have a learning curve. The included instructions are so brief as to be almost useless, though they do explain how to assemble the top. (There are detailed instructions and videos available on the toy manufacturer's web site. Go to the official Hasbro site, choose ‚ÄúBrands‚Äù, and then ‚ÄúBeyblade Burst‚Äù.)

It took some practice to get a good ‚ÄúRip‚Äù (launch). It also took me awhile to figure out that the launcher wouldn't work unless the strip was inserted in the correct slot (e.g., right for a right-spin top), that the top needed to be rotated slightly onto the launcher, and that the tops were meant to be dropped into the stadium (not started on the stadium floor).

These tops require two people and two tops for play, because the tops are intended to be launched simultaneously for each battle. I think that single players can use the accompanying Beyblade Burst app (available for iOS and Android), which adds the tops you own to your collection in the app once you scan a code from the top.

Hasbro's original price for these tops was apparently about $13. Prices are higher now, and vary quite a bit among online sellers.

title: ‚ÄúStarter Pack‚Äù Contains One Left-Spin Top, No Stadium
text:
This BEYBLADE BURST EVOLUTION SWITCHSTRIKE STARTER PACK (Fafnir F3) contains a Beyblade Burst Evolution Fafnir F3 (one of the few left-spin tops), and a launcher that can be used for either left-spin or right-spin tops. You will need to purchase a ‚Äúbattle stadium‚Äù separately (e.g., [[ASIN:B01F6VS3ZG Beyblade Burst Beystadium]]).

Hasbro's Burst Evolution battling tops are fun toys, but they have a learning curve. The included instructions are so brief as to be almost useless, though they do explain how to assemble the top. (There are detailed instructions and videos available on the toy manufacturer's web site. Go to the official Hasbro site, choose ‚ÄúBrands‚Äù, and then ‚ÄúBeyblade Burst‚Äù.)

It took some practice to get a good ‚ÄúRip‚Äù (launch). It also took me awhile to figure out that the launcher wouldn't work unless the strip was inserted in the correct slot (e.g., left for a left-spin top), that the top needed to be rotated slightly onto the launcher, and that the tops were meant to be dropped into the stadium (not started on the stadium floor).

The parts for these Burst Evolution tops can be interchanged to create custom tops with different strengths and weaknesses. I would strongly advise any adult who is purchasing one of these tops for a youngster to find out exactly which model it is that the kid wants. The tops perform very differently, depending on their weight and on features such as the type of tip (e.g., rollerball). The back of each toy card gives details on the features (e.g., type (attack or defense), weight, endurance, etc.) of the included top.

These tops require two people and two tops for play, because the tops are intended to be launched simultaneously for each battle. I think that single players can use the accompanying Beyblade Burst app (available for iOS and Android), which adds the tops you own to your collection in the app, once you scan in a code from the top.

title: Fun Toy With Online Player App
text:
Hasbro's Beyblade Burst Evolution battling tops are fun toys, but they have a learning curve. The included instructions are so brief as to be almost useless, though they do explain how to assemble the top. (There are detailed instructions and videos available on the toy manufacturer's web site. Go to the official Hasbro site, choose ‚ÄúBrands‚Äù, and then ‚ÄúBeyblade Burst‚Äù.) The back of the toy card gives details on the features (e.g., type (attack or defense), weight, endurance, etc.) of the included top.

This BEYBLADE BURST EVOLUTION SWITCHSTRIKE STARTER PACK (Roktavor R3) contains a Roktavor 3 (a right-spin top), and a launcher that can be used for either left-spin or right-spin tops. You will need to purchase a ‚Äúbattle stadium‚Äù separately (e.g., [[ASIN:B01F6VS3ZG Beyblade Burst Beystadium]]).

These tops require two people and two tops for play, because the tops are intended to be launched simultaneously for each battle. My efforts to launch two tops in close succession weren't very successful, and the resulting battles weren't very satisfying. I think that single players can use the accompanying Beyblade Burst app (available for iOS and Android). It's an extremely slick, easy-to-use game app that simulates stadium battles between your own Burst tops‚Äîyou can scan a code from the card or from a section of the top to add the top to your collection within the app.

The parts for these Burst Evolution tops can be interchanged to create custom tops with different strengths and weaknesses. I would strongly advise any adult who is purchasing one of these tops for a youngster to find out exactly which model it is that the kid wants. The tops perform very differently, depending on their weight and on features such as the type of tip (e.g., rollerball).

Hasbro's original price for these tops was apparently about $13. Prices are higher now, and vary quite a bit among online sellers.

Fun Toy With Online Player App

title: Fun Toy Requires Stadium (Purchased Separately), Two Players With Tops
text:
Hasbro's Beyblade Burst Evolution battling tops are fun toys, but they have a learning curve. The included instructions are so brief as to be almost useless, though they do explain how to assemble the top. (There are detailed instructions and videos available on the toy manufacturer's web site. Go to the official Hasbro site, choose ‚ÄúBrands‚Äù, and then ‚ÄúBeyblade Burst‚Äù.) The back of the toy card gives details on the features (e.g., type (attack or defense), weight, endurance, etc.) of the included top.

This BEYBLADE BURST EVOLUTION SWITCHSTRIKE STARTER PACK (Wyvron W3) contains a Wyvron W3 (a right-spin top), and a launcher that can be used for either left-spin or right-spin tops. You will need to purchase a ‚Äúbattle stadium‚Äù separately (e.g., [[ASIN:B01F6VS3ZG Beyblade Burst Beystadium]]).

These tops require two people and two tops for play, because the tops are intended to be launched simultaneously for each battle. My efforts to launch two tops in close succession weren't very successful, and the resulting battles weren't very satisfying.

It took some practice to get a good ‚ÄúRip‚Äù (launch). It also took me awhile to figure out that the launcher wouldn't work unless the strip was inserted in the correct slot (e.g., right for a right-spin top), that the top needed to be rotated slightly onto the launcher, and that the tops were meant to be dropped into the stadium (not started on the stadium floor). (I thought originally that the starter-pack launcher would give either a right or a left spin to any Beyblade top.)

The parts for these Burst Evolution tops can be interchanged to create custom tops with different strengths and weaknesses. I would strongly advise any adult who is purchasing one of these tops for a youngster to find out exactly which model it is that the kid wants. The tops perform very differently, depending on their weight and on features such as the type of tip (e.g., rollerball).

Hasbro's original price for these tops was apparently about $13. Prices are higher now, and vary quite a bit among online sellers.

title: All-Wooden Game Set Delivers Pretty Good Value
text:
This MAINSTREET CLASSICS DUTCHMAN 3-IN-1 COMBO FOLDING BOARD GAME SET delivers pretty good value for the money (about $37 on Amazon). Maybe it's a bit expensive for what it is, but it's all made of wood. On the outside of the case is an inlaid wooden chess/checkers board; on the inside, a somewhat compressed inlaid wooden backgammon board. The case folds closed (with a handle) so that it can hold wooden checkers, wooden chess pieces, wooden dice cups, and backgammon dice.

My game set has none of the quality control issues complained of by other reviewers (no blobs of glue, loose hinges, etc.). The chess pieces won't win any design awards, but they are playable because they are easily recognizable as pawn, knight, rook, etc. The checkers are small, but are reasonably sized for a portable game set. The case is sanded smooth and has a lacquer finish.

I think this is a great game set to carry along on vacation, or to leave year-round at a cabin or second home. It is a decent starter set for kids, especially for kids interested in learning chess.

title: Medium-Sized Model With Lots of Pieces; Fun to Play With
text:
This LEGO STAR WARS EPISODE VIII RESISTANCE BOMBER BUILDING KIT (75188; 780 Pieces) is fun to build; and when you're finished, you have great ‚ÄúStar Wars‚Äù toy to play with. The set has 780 pieces, and the finished model is 13‚Äù high x 15‚Äù long x 11‚Äù wide, which makes it a medium-sized model.

The model's working features include a bomb release, some spring-loaded shooters, rear gun turrets that open for a minifig, elevating rear guns, a 2-minifig front cockpit, and a removable top section (for easy access). There are several included character minifigs.

I love LEGO building sets (the larger and more complicated the better), and I love the LEGO ‚ÄúStar Wars‚Äù sets for their accurate depiction of the battleships and machines seen in the movies. This model really captures the look of the Resistance Bombers from Episode VIII (‚ÄúThe Last Jedi‚Äù).

title: Fun Fishing-Themed Set Originated as Amateur LEGO Builder's Idea
text:
This LEGO IDEAS OLD FISHING STORE BUILDING KIT (21310) is about the same size (12‚Äù high, 9‚Äù wide) as the big Creator Expert town buildings. It's different, though, because one wall swings open for play (like a dollhouse). It's filled with fun details‚Äîa store with bait and tackle boxes, a spearfishing gun, cash register, and fishing gear; a tower with a removable roof; a sea captain and other minifigs; a cat and a seagull; and more. There are 2049 pieces, so it's a satisfying, interesting, entertaining build.

The set originated as a model submitted by an amateur builder (non-LEGO employee) to the online LEGO Ideas community. After it gained sufficient community support (currently 10,000 votes, which usually takes months), LEGO experts reviewed it, and decided to offer it as an official LEGO set.

title: Charming Pair of Bright-Colored Potted Flowers
text: This LEGO FLOWER DISPLAY SET (100 pieces (40187)) is a quick build that produces a charming pair of bright-colored potted flowers (a rose and a daisy) for your desk, bookshelf, table, or windowsill.  You can use the simple instructions as the basis for your own designs for other flowers to add to your little ‚Äúgarden‚Äù‚Äîthe flowers use standard LEGO pieces.  (Use the set number above online at the LEGO website to identify the specific ‚Äúreplacement pieces‚Äù.  The set is listed at a lower price (less than Amazon's $19) on the website, but it was sold out at the time of this review.)

title: Works Well for Stroke-Disabled Person's Hand Therapy
text: This PETIT COLLAGE RABBIT WOOD STACKING TOY works well for my unusual purpose‚Äîto give my stroke-disabled husband a new and different hand-therapy challenge.  The rocking base makes it slightly harder to stack the wooden pieces onto the center post.  The fact that the differently shaped and colored pieces are stackable in any order (except for the rabbit's head) adds visual variety to the therapy exercise.  The wooden parts are durable, and the rabbit is seriously cute.

title: Great ‚ÄúQuick‚Äù Project for Jigsaw Puzzle Expert
text:
This RAVENSBURGER VIEW OF TOWER BRIDGE JIGSAW PUZZLE (1000 Piece) is a great ‚Äúquick‚Äù project for a jigsaw puzzle expert. It took me about 2¬Ω days, working several hours at a stretch in four or maybe five extended sessions. (I get kind of compulsive about jigsaw puzzles, always hunting for ‚Äújust one more piece‚Äù before stopping.)

The puzzle consists of five main parts: the water and tower bases (easy because of the colors); the tower decks, suspension cables, and pedestrian walkways (easy because of the colors, patterns, and straight lines); the towers (moderately difficult because there are two similar towers); the autumn leaves (hard, because there are a lot of similarly-colored pieces with ‚Äúabstract‚Äù patterning); and the sky (hard, despite the clouds, because there are a lot of pieces to place by subtle color differences and by shape).

These different sections draw on all of an expert's skills, but there aren't so many pieces that the assembler gets sick of the photo before finishing the puzzle. One thousand pieces make the puzzle a lot more challenging and satisfying than an ordinary 500-piece tabletop puzzle, but the photo is an easy one that reduces the difficulty level.

As always with Ravensburger puzzles, this one is excellently made, with unique pieces that fit together in only one way. The soft-click connections tell you immediately whether or not you have joined the correct pieces.

title: ‚ÄúBuild and Swap‚Äù Advertising Seems Overstated
text:
What I like about this LEGO DISNEY PRINCESS MULAN'S Training Day 41151 BUILDING KIT (104 Piece)‚Äîwhich is obviously marketed to girls‚Äîis that it features a strong, active female. Mulan is at home, but her home features a sword, a catapult, and a spinning training dummy, not just a cherry tree in bloom, a fan, and a tea set. The foal Khan is included, though Mulan can't ride (she's wearing a skirt).

What I don't like about this set is the ‚ÄúBuild and Swap‚Äù balloon on the box. LEGO pieces are generally interchangeable, so it made me think that this set was part of a Mulan series of similar sets. But it isn't‚Äîthe other 2018 Disney Princess sets are Sleeping Beauty's Fairytale Castle, Ariel's Royal Celebration, Cinderella's Dream Castle, and Elsa's Market Adventure. None of these are compatible, theme-wise, with the Mulan set.

Apparently ‚ÄúBuild and Swap‚Äù merely refers to the fact that some of the completed elements (e.g., cherry tree, catapult) can swap positions in Mulan's home. (See my photo.) This doesn't seem interesting enough to warrant special advertising, especially advertising that suggests the child needs to collect more sets for swapping.

Priced about $15 on Amazon, this small LEGO set is affordable as a gift, but isn't exactly cheap. However, anything with the ‚ÄúDisney‚Äù trademark always costs more, and it's a cute little set that Mulan fans should enjoy assembling and playing with.

title: Satisfying, Highly Varied Build; Bat-Dune Buggy Is Fun to Play With
text:
This LEGO BAT-DUNE BUGGY 70918 BUILDING KIT (198 pieces, tied in with the LEGO Batman Movie) is about a 45-minute build for someone who's already familiar with the LEGO parts commonly used in vehicles. With 198 pieces, there are a lot of parts to identify, so it will take longer for anyone new to LEGO.

It's a highly varied, satisfying build, even for an adult. There is quite a bit of sideways building, and there are some combinations that take some attention to figure out. As always, the instructions are clear.

The finished Bat-Dune Buggy shoots LEGO dots from side-mounted guns. There is a rubber-band suspension that is activated by pressing down on the tail fins. It's a fairly solid build, though the back section can pop off if you press too hard. The buggy has big wheels that turn. (You may need to turn the front wheels by hand at first to loosen them up. The front wheels are not mounted on an axle like the back wheels.)

There are two minifigs, Batman and Boomerang Man. Batman's head has two faces with different expressions; the minifig has a marvelous fabric cape. Priced about $16 on Amazon, I think that this set returns good value for the money. When finished, the Bat-Dune Buggy is fun to play with.

title: Cute Hulk Figure Arrives in Solid Plastic Display Case
text:
Incredible Hulk fans of all ages will like this little guy, the MARVEL MIGHTY MUGGS HULK #3. He stands about 4‚Äù high, and arrives attached to a solid plastic base, under a clear plastic dome. You may want to save the domed box, because it doubles as a nice display case. The figure attaches to the base with easy-to-turn plastic bolts (use a coin, such as a quarter). The dome has a hole in the top that lets you reach in to change the figure's three expressions by pushing down on the head.

That's all it is‚Äîa Hulk figure with three different cartoon expressions‚Äîbut it's cute, and I love it. It seems to be solidly constructed, and it will probably stand up to a reasonable amount of abuse in the course of children's play. It does stand up on its own when removed from the base.

title: Comes With Only One Character Truck; Lots of Stickers to Apply
text:
I love Hot Wheels playsets, but I think that the traditional playsets with standard cars and special stunts (e.g., the spiral tower) are still the best. They're the most versatile, because they can be connected into all sorts of different layouts. This HOT WHEELS STAR WARS MILLENNIUM FALCON PLAYSET (with Movie Ticket) was kind of disappointing, because it comes with only one Star-Wars-themed truck (Chewbacca). Without purchasing more of the character cars and trucks, you can't come close to the exciting, fun experience promised by the product page ad video.

The set is simple to assemble, but there are a LOT of stickers to apply. This playset can be attached to other Hot Wheels playsets, but it's mostly a standalone Star Wars shoot-em-up-and-crash-em toy. There aren't a whole lot of play options (although there are more options than with most HW stunt playsets). The sound effects consist of shooting sounds and Chewbacca wails.

Priced around $50 on Amazon, it doesn't deliver a lot of bang for your Star Wars buck. (I think that Millennium Falcon toys without the cars and chutes are more versatile and fun.) Of course any Star Wars toy costs extra because of the Disney licensing fees.

title: Taken Aback by Sheer Size of Playset
text:
When this HOT WHEELS SUPER ULTIMATE GARAGE PLAYSET arrived, I was taken aback by its sheer size‚Äîthe box takes up more space than my foldaway single-person camping bed! Definitely you should NOT order this Hot Wheels set unless you have a whole room or a large space that's available for an extensive, semi-permanent Hot Wheels layout.

I love Hot Wheels cars, track sets, and stunts, but this set is too much of a good thing. It's too big for my living room floor space, and too big for my closet storage space. It also requires too much effort to build and take apart again for storage.

title: Fun Toy Crawls When Pushed, Shoots Springloaded Bolts
text:
This LEGO STAR WARS FIRST ORDER HEAVY SCOUT WALKER BUILDING KIT (75177; 554 Piece) makes a fun toy‚Äîwhen you push it, wheels hidden underneath make it ‚Äúcrawl‚Äù (the legs go up and down); and it shoots long, red, springloaded plastic bolts. Basically this is a Technic build (using mostly Technic pieces and connectors), which makes it a little more difficult than, say, a City or Creator build (using standard bricks, plates, etc.).

The instructions are crystal clear, as always with LEGO. The trickiest connections in the build are circled, and there's no problem as long as you regularly check to see that all the moving parts are still able to move after you add something.

The set comes with four minifigs (General Hux, a First Order Gunner, a Resistance Trooper, and a First Order Flametrooper).

This is an interesting build‚Äîit always amazes me, the way that the LEGO master builders use LEGO pieces to replicate machinery and mechanical movements. With 554 pieces in this set, the $49.99 price seems reasonable to me, especially since LEGO must pay Disney for the use of the Star Wars trademark and toy design.

title: Small LEGO Kit Really Shines‚ÄîInteresting to Build; Creates Fun Toy With Springloaded Bolt Launchers
text:
There are some LEGO kits that really shine, and this LEGO STAR WARS RESISTANCE TRANSPORT POD BUILDING KIT (75176; 294 Pieces) is one of them. It's an interesting build, with some elements attached underneath (studs not on top), many added to the sides, and several specialized parts (e.g., canopy, bolt launchers). The finished build is solid, and provides a toy that's fun to play with (even for adults).

The pod has room inside for all three minifigs (Rose, Finn, BB8). The pod canopy, rear compartment roof, and side storage compartment door lift off and go back on easily. The cockpit has holders for Finn's and Rose's weapons. The storage compartment has extra weapons.

The pod has a side turret gun that swivels for aiming when you turn the big knob at the back. The turret gun has a trigger that launches single rounds. The pod shoots long red bolts (rounded tips, not pointed) from underneath the cockpit. (Two special-to-the-kit bricks have springs inside that work as launchers). The pod feels good in your hand.

The kit takes two hours or less to build; it uses some Technic connectors in addition to standard bricks and plates. The instructions are crystal clear. There are quite a few stickers to add to the bricks, but the graphics are nice when all the stickers are in place.

This is a great small LEGO kit, one that I'll be keeping for display and play.

title: Size of Model Allows Lots of Detail
text:
This LEGO STAR WARS ‚ÄúKYLO REN'S TIE FIGHTER‚Äù BUILDING KIT (75179; 630 Piece) produces a very large model, which automatically makes it one of my favorite LEGO sets. The larger the model, the longer it takes to build, and the more detail emerges as the pieces go together.

During the build, it's always interesting to see how the LEGO designers solve construction and appearance problems (e.g., attaching parts horizontally, or making surfaces appear to be rounded when using straight-sided bricks and plates).

In this particular model, I love the included minifigs (Kylo Ren, a First Order TIE Pilot, a First Order Stormtrooper, and a BB-9E droid). The two working, spring-loaded shooters make the model fun to play with.

As always, the LEGO pieces are precisely made, and snap tightly together. The step-by-step assembly instructions are easy to follow, and result in a solid build. The model is fairly heavy when complete, because it contains a lot of bricks! The pieces are standard LEGO components, so they can be used to build other projects whenever you get tired of the model.

title: Excellent Girls' Building Toy, Based on ‚ÄúMonster High‚Äù Dolls
text:
Building toys for girls are a good thing, and this MEGA CONSTRUX MONSTER HIGH CARNIVAL BUILDING SET that's based on the ‚ÄùMonster High‚Äù dolls is an excellent one. The ‚ÄúScaris Wheel‚Äù isn't motorized, but it's a solid build that moves freely (both wheel and hanging gondola chairs). There are some tricky connections in the wheel, but nothing that's too hard to figure out.

The included action figures (Cleo de Nile and Deuce Gorgon) are made of semi-soft plastic, jointed, and printed in full color with great detail. (Yes, the Deuce Gorgon figure has green eyes under those sunglasses‚Äù!) The figures come pre-assembled, but can be taken apart (hair, head, clothing, accessories) and reassembled. To carry out the carnival theme, Cleo holds a pretzel, and Deuce has an apple on a stick. Both figures can ride on the Scaris Wheel.

The Scaris Wheel and its supporting tower are decorated with little skulls. There is a ticket booth that attaches to the wheel tower and swings out (or can be removed to stand alone). I love the dark-charcoal-and-blue-mottled bricks that are used in the support structures.

In my experience, Mega Bloks are slightly harder to assemble than LEGO bricks. The don't seem to be manufactured with the same precision, so they don't snap together cleanly.

Also, the Mega Bloks assembly directions are harder to follow than LEGO instructions, because they are written as ‚Äúexploded‚Äù add-a-brick diagrams rather than as diagrams showing how the model looks after each brick is added. Still, learning to understand exploded diagrams will stand kids in good stead when they grow up and start assembling furniture!

title: Kit Produces Posable Elite Praetorian Guard Figure With Fascinating Double-Knife-Tipped Weapon
text:
I love LEGO building kits, but the LEGO Star Wars figures are NOT my favorites. I prefer the regular Technic and Creator kits, which have fewer specialty parts that can't be used for anything else.

This LEGO STAR WARS ‚ÄúELITE PRAETORIAN GUARD‚Äù BUILDING KIT (75529; 92 Pieces) takes about half an hour to assemble. It produces a posable figure with a fascinating double-knife-tipped weapon that moves from side to side when you move the figure's shoulders (from the back of the figure).

However, new poses must be done with care, because the ball joints are stiff and the armor is clipped vertically onto ball connectors. There's no good place to hold the body when you reposition the arms and legs, so it's easy to knock pieces off, or to pull the figure apart. The knife weapon must be taken apart at one hand to reposition it.

The kit uses various Technic connectors, so it helps to be familiar with these when you assemble the figure. (The kit is slightly harder to assemble than a kit with traditional bricks.) As always with LEGO kits, it's interesting to see how the specialty parts all combine into a final build that looks very different from the individual pieces.

title: Kit Produces Posable Rey Figure With Cool Lightsaber Arm
text:
I love LEGO building kits, but the LEGO Star Wars figures are NOT my favorites. I prefer the regular Technic and Creator kits, which have fewer specialty parts that can't be used for anything else.

This LEGO STAR WARS ‚ÄúREY‚Äù BUILDING KIT (75528; 85 Pieces) takes about half an hour to assemble. It produces a posable figure with a rather cool Lightsaber arm that moves up and down when you twist a control at the back of the figure. Rey's head looks great, and her body is printed with nice armor and cross-draped fabric.

However, every pose must be done with care, because the ball joints are stiff and the armor is clipped vertically onto ball connectors. There's no good place to hold the body when you reposition the arms and legs, so it's easy to knock pieces off, or to pull the figure apart.

The kit uses various Technic connectors, so it helps to be familiar with these when you assemble the figure. (The kit is slightly harder to assemble than a kit with traditional bricks.) As always with LEGO kits, it's interesting to see how the specialty parts all combine into a final build that looks very different from the individual pieces.

title: High-Quality Building Set, But Builds Don't Look Much Like Intended Things
text:
This CLICFORMERS BASIC SET (150 Piece, Multicolor) is a high-quality building set. The pieces are solid, uniform, smooth-edged, and easily snapped together. However, the pieces aren't particularly versatile--most builds seem to use a chain of connected basic pieces rolled or wrapped around an accessory piece, or folded into boxes.

Also, the finished builds don't look much like a ‚Äúduck‚Äù or a ‚Äúpenguin‚Äù or a ‚Äúnecklace‚Äù or a ‚Äútruck‚Äù. It takes imagination to see the build as the thing it is intended to be. To me, the builds always look like an aggregation of Clicformers pieces, instead of transforming visually into an entirely different object.

This set includes a booklet of clear instructions for a variety of builds. There is also a sheet of stickers to apply to the pieces, either for decoration or for birds' or animals' eyes. The set is fun to play with, if you like building toys.

I think that LEGO sets give better value, because you can build so many different, recognizable things from the basic bricks (LEGO, or LEGO Duplo for younger children), without needing a lot of special connectors. If Clicformers offer something that LEGO doesn't, I don't know what it is. Clicformers certainly aren't cheaper (as are K'nex and Mega Blox building sets).

title: Beautiful Hair, Earrings, Gown; Doll Made for Display, Not Play
text:
This BARBIE 2017 HOLIDAY TERESA DOLL (Brunette) has beautiful brunette hair, with light brown highlighting to add interest. The full-skirted, full-length gown, made of dark red, sparkly metallic fabric, is to die for, with the skirt slit to above the knee. The earrings are lovely (though they don't actually move like dangly earrings, because they're made in one piece from plastic).

The doll is intended more for display by collectors than for play. Both arms move at the shoulder joint, but the left arm is permanently bent into a hand-on-the-hip pose. The hair is very fragile--some of it started to fly away even as I was removing the doll from the box. The doll comes with a nice little stand.

The giant star has costume jewelry ‚Äúrubies‚Äù set into the points--very pretty. The star attaches to the gown with two prongs that fit into loops on the back of the bodice. (The star doesn't quite work as a tree ornament, because of the prongs.)

Removing the doll from the box is a job for an older child or an adult. The cardboard backing (carrying the doll) is held inside the clear plastic display box with plastic tabs that must be flattened to release the backing. Both the skirt of the gown and the doll's long hair are sewn to the cardboard backing. The doll's head, waist, hands, and feet are secured by clear plastic bands and tabs that are taped to the backing. Clipping all of these ‚Äúrestraints‚Äù requires fine scissors, a good eye, and a steady hand to avoid damaging the hair or gown.

title: Satisfying Build; Lots of Play Potential; Great Attention to Detail
text:
As an adult fan of LEGO, I really love assembling the City sets. The beauty of these sets is the careful attention to detail. In this LEGO CITY ‚ÄúBUS STATION‚Äù BUILDING KIT (60154), for example, the minifig passengers include a person in a wheelchair, and two people with bicycles. The bicycles even clip onto a ‚Äúrack‚Äù on the back of the big bus, or fit into a ‚Äúlocking station‚Äù alongside the bus shelter.

The set also includes a newsstand (complete with seller and printed newspaper tiles), a bus driver, and an office worker. Stickers add bus schedules and advertisements to the shelter, and handicapped access decals for the bus doors.

With 337 regular LEGO pieces, this set provides a satisfying amount of building time. Also, there are a lot of options for play after the build is complete. The bus station complements other City sets (e.g., train station, police station, demolition site, etc.), if you have space for setting up a whole city.

title: ‚ÄúPeople Pack‚Äù Minifigs Add More Life to City Building Sets
text:
As an adult fan of LEGO, I really love assembling the Creator and City sets with fancy buildings. These usually come with minifigs, but sometimes the streets and buildings seem empty without more people. The City ‚ÄúPeople Packs‚Äù solve this problem! This LEGO ‚ÄúFUN AT THE BEACH‚Äù BUILDING KIT (60153) gives you a wide selection of minifigs attired in swimsuits, wetsuits, and playsuits, with appropriate accessories.

As always, it was fun to see how the brick-built accessories (sand castle, lounge chair, volleyball net, lifeguard tower, beach umbrella, ice cream stand, hammock) transformed from regular LEGO bricks into things that looked like something else. This set has a lot of specialized accessory bricks (metal detector, sand pail, Dalmatian dog, porpoise, lobster, kayak with paddle, windsurfing board, banana, fish, shovel, volleyball, camera, binoculars, boombox, cellphone, bullhorn) that are nice to have.

The minifigs can be assembled per the instructions, or mixed and matched. There are people of different ages (from grandmother to kids), and many different hairstyles (short, long and loose, braids, buns) in different colors (gray, brown, beige, yellow).

These beach-attired minifigs are just what you need if you're creating your own ocean- or beach-themed models from regular LEGO bricks.

title: Dazzling Ice Palace Is One of LEGO's Best Efforts
text:
I'm a lover of the really big LEGO sets, especially the Creator buildings (e.g., Cinderella's Castle; the Detective's Office) and the Technic heavy construction equipment models (e.g., the Bucket Wheel Excavator). In my opinion, this medium-sized set, the DISNEY FROZEN ELSA'S MAGICAL ICE PALACE (41148) is one of LEGO's very best efforts.

The set has lots of beautiful transparent blue bricks, and a couple of specialized large panels for the castle that are transparent blue with embedded silver sparkles. The transparent blue bricks exactly match Elsa's blue from the ‚ÄúFrozen‚Äù movie.

If you've seen the movie, you will love the spiral staircase that expands and rises up with a twist of the ball at the top--very much like the icy castle walls that rose up magically in response to Elsa's sweeping movements in the movie. As is always true with LEGO sets, it's fun to see, as you build, how the simple bricks become furniture, chandeliers, doorways, and other details.

The set has minifigures of Olaf, Elsa, Anna, a snow monster, and small snowmen. The balconied castle is furnished with a chandelier, a bed with coverlet, a table and chairs, a music stand, and a kitchen. Stickers printed on sparkly silver paper go onto the moving castle doors to complete the dazzling look of the ice palace. And despite all the detail, this set is fairly easy to build.

title: Tiny Details Are Hard to Spot in This Expert Challenger Jigsaw
text:
This RAVENSBURGER ‚ÄúCINQUE TERRE, ITALY‚Äù PUZZLE (1500 Pieces) is one of the most difficult Ravensburger jigsaws that I've encountered. Because it's so large--it covered my work table--the photo is blown up, and the picture seemed out of focus as I worked. The tiny, important details (and the colors of various areas) are hard to spot on the individual puzzle pieces. Probably about 10-15 percent of the pieces must be located and placed by their shapes.

Still, it's a high-quality puzzle. The fact that all Ravensburger puzzle pieces interlock with great accuracy is the thing that makes it possible to assemble this expert challenger jigsaw.

title: Well-Made Wooden Learning Toy Has Charming Turtle Faces
text:
This JANOD I WOOD TURTLES, MIXED learning toy is very well-made. I love the cute, smiling, painted turtle faces! The stacking parts are colorful, which makes it fun to stack them according to the correct shapes--or not, if you like to color outside the lines, or to think outside the box!

The turtles themselves do NOT stack, but they DO link together. This durable wooden toy is a good choice for teaching color-matching, shape-matching, and fine motor skills. The stacking parts go easily onto the spindles, and are easily rotated to make the shapes (circles, stars, squares, hexagons) line up.

title: Hard-to-Identify, Hard-to-Set-Up Buildings Destroy Fun of Assembling Kit
text:
This 4D CITYSCAPE CHICAGO SKYLINE PUZZLE is great in concept, but falls way short in the execution. It's a three-part puzzle. First you assemble a standard jigsaw (an 1867 Chicago street map). Next you assemble a foam-based jigsaw with identical interlocking tabs (a modern Chicago street map) that goes atop the first jigsaw. Third you add three-dimensional plastic buildings to the foam jigsaw.

The first jigsaw is difficult, especially in the large blue Lake Michigan area, but the street names and the boats on the lake help enough to make this an expert-but-fairly-easy jigsaw. The second foam jigsaw comes partly assembled, with several large pieces, and is very easy, taking less than an hour. (Unless you separate all the smallest foam street-grid pieces, which will require a lot of close comparison with the color map, and a lot of extra unsatisfying puzzle time, to reassemble.)

The third part, adding the buildings, is where the whole puzzle concept breaks down. Unless you're familiar with Chicago already, the buildings are hard to identify by comparing the plastic pieces with the photographs on the color buildings poster. You have to identify each building by finding its numbered location on the color map, and then matching the appearance of the roof to the line drawing of the roof found in the punch-out foam puzzle piece at the location in the foam map. (With some similar buildings, this is quite difficult, and you have to check the size of the plastic bases as well. It also helps to know how to read architectural diagrams.)

Finally, inserting the buildings is a major problem. If you punch out the foam piece where the building goes in, you will NOT be able to tell how the building is oriented to the street and the buildings around it. If you don't punch out the foam piece, but merely jam the building down onto it, the building will fall over whenever you jostle the foam as you add more buildings. Another problem is that some historic buildings are gold and the rest are silver-gray.

The puzzle kit also includes a set of silver-gray "generic" buildings that you can add to make the Chicago downtown look more like a skyscraper city. However, you don't know when these buildings were built, so inserting them destroys the historical timeline that helps you see how Chicago grew.

I was really excited about this puzzle, because I wanted to see all the buildings added after I departed Chicago in the sixties. However, adding the buildings was fiddly and far too much of a hassle, so I bailed on the project after 25 buildings. (If I ever decide to go back and finish it, I will glue the buildings in place atop the foam.)

In sum, although the standard jigsaw is fun to assemble, it is overpriced at the cost of the entire kit (about $30 on Amazon). The rest of the kit was a big disappointment. Now I think I'll try to find a book of photographs that will show me how Chicago has grown since 1867, or since the sixties.

title: Ill-Fitting Model-Building Pieces Negate Value of Manual Describing Experiments
text:
Unlike the other reviewers, I found the manual for this THAMES & KOSMOS GYROSCOPES & FLYWHEELS SCIENCE KIT to be fascinating. The experiments are interesting, and the explanations of the physics principles that are demonstrated by the experiments are clear enough. The assembly diagrams were also easy to follow, once I understood that the gyroscope and fly wheel come already assembled, and once I found the instructions for using the zip cords (on the opening booklet page, not counting the cover).

However, there can be no forgiving the fact that the building pieces are hard to fit together. This is a manufacturing problem that needs to be fixed. The manual is of little value unless the experiments can be performed--the manual and models are meant to be used together to teach the scientific principles.

title: Cutest Bear Yet!
text:
This year's Amazon collectible bear, the GUND 2016 PLUSH BEAR, may be the cutest yet! I love the red snowflake-print hat and mittens. The bear is a little bit smaller than the 2015 bear (with the red-and-white striped cap). It is a good-sized, high-quality, Gund bear that is very soft and cuddly. The Amazon logo is embroidered on the bear's left hind foot.

I think this bear gives great value for the money (about $19 on Amazon). Amazon usually offers the bear free with various toy and gift card offers, but I'm a collector, so I ordered mine early (before Black Friday). Last year's bear sold out very quickly (before December 25).

title: Start a Family Tradition, or Give a Small Child a Sturdy, Colorful Toy
text:
This BRIO DELUXE BIRTHDAY TRAIN is a cute, sturdy toy, with both wooden and plastic parts. I love the idea of using this toy as the centerpiece in a small child's birthday celebrations (ages 1-6 years). What a nice family tradition that would be!

The train is a little large for a table centerpiece, but the large size means it will photograph well when it's displaying a child's age on his/her birthday. The set includes wooden blocks with numbers 1 to 6, but you don't really have to stop at 6 years. You can easily draw or print the rest of the numbers you need (0,7,8,9, and duplicates of 1 through 9), tape them over the blocks, and set up as many as two number blocks in the two cars. You can celebrate birthdays from 1 to 99!

Also, I think that a small child would have a lot of fun playing with this colorful little train. The two cars couple and uncouple easily, and have a lot of room for loading in small toys like zoo animals or building blocks. When the locomotive and cars are coupled together, the wheels turn freely, so the train is easy to push along a table or floor, hauling its load.

title: Battery-Powered Launcher Makes Setup Easy
text:
This HOT WHEELS CRISS CROSS CRASH TRACK SET is a sure-fire child-pleaser, because the whole point of it is to set up vehicle crashes and near crashes. Strangely, there is only ONE Hot Wheels car included with this "crash-producer" set (although inexpensive, compatible, standard Hot Wheels cars are readily available at supermarkets and drug stores).

The setup is simple--just connect the track sections to the main launcher section in four wide loops. There are no twisting spirals or complicated loops to assemble "just so", because the battery-powered launcher supplies the power that keeps the cars moving along the tracks until they crash. The launcher requires four "D" (standard flashlight) batteries (batteries NOT included).

The track in this set is the same track that is used in standard Hot Wheels gravity-car layouts. The launcher can be connected to other standard track sets (in the same fashion as the many other Hot Wheels "stunt" sets), so it's a nice choice for expanding children's existing Hot Wheels track layouts.

title: "Pre-Assembled" Statue of Liberty--Jigsaw Puzzle Pieces Construct Statue's Base
text:
This RAVENSBURGER STATUE OF LIBERTY 3D PUZZLE (108-Piece) makes a nice souvenir of a visit to Liberty Island, but it's not a great 3D puzzle. All of the flat plastic jigsaw puzzle pieces are used to construct the truncated-pyramid platform (a brown, brick-and-stone building in real life) that forms the base of the Statue of Liberty. There are only two "puzzle pieces" for Lady Liberty--a molded green plastic statue with a golden torch, and a molded green crown that snaps onto the head of the statue.

The plastic jigsaw pieces are nicely printed to look like the statue's base, but the brown tones and pictures of bricks are boring to assemble. The jigsaw pieces are numbered on the backs to give the correct order of construction. You can assemble them by the numbers if you want a fairly easy puzzle (or if you're new to building 3D puzzles), or you can assemble them the traditional way by matching up the pictures on the fronts of the pieces.

Some of the jigsaw pieces are hinged, to make the corners of the 4-sided base. You just bend the pieces gently in the middle before using them to connect other pieces. The statue snaps onto the platform, and the platform snaps (with little clips) onto a laminated cardboard piece that is printed to look like the plaza that surrounds the real statue.

I'm a big, big fan of Ravensburger jigsaws, and I love the Ravensburger 3D-puzzle globes. But I was very disappointed with this puzzle, because the Statue of Liberty itself is "pre-assembled" (except for the crown). Because the puzzle itself is of high quality, and produces a decent Statue of Liberty model, I rate this 3D puzzle at 3 stars ("It's okay" on the official Amazon scale).

title: Non-Interlocking Pieces, Diagonal Cut, Repeating Design Elements Make Puzzle Challenging Even for Jigsaw Puzzle Experts
text:
This EUROGRAPHICS TREE OF LIFE BY GUSTAV KLIMT 1000-PIECE PUZZLE is a challenger even for jigsaw puzzle experts. The design is full of repetitive elements (e.g., the tree-branch spirals, the gilt triangles). The puzzle pieces fit together well, but they are NOT interlocking, and there are many, many weirdly shaped pieces. Worst of all (or best of all if you love difficult jigsaws), the puzzle is cut on the diagonal, so you don't have the usual rows and columns to help you out with assembly by puzzle piece shapes and color areas.

There are some clues to help with the assembly‚Äîthe painting has colored triangles on the left, colored squares on the right--but you must constantly refer to the photo on the puzzle box to locate the recognizable elements on the pieces. Success requires sorting of puzzle pieces, accurate placement of recognizable elements inside the puzzle frame before the background is filled in, and a generally highly organized approach to assembly.

This puzzle is a terrible choice for a group project‚Äînot only because of the need to place elements in position before attacking the spirals in the background, but also because the non-interlocking pieces are easily jarred apart after recognizable elements are assembled. The shapes are so weird, I even had a little bit of difficulty locating all of the edge pieces for the frame, to get the puzzle started.

This puzzle is ONLY for the most dedicated, highly expert, jigsaw puzzle fans. I doubt that children or most retirees will have the patience to stick with it to completion. Because the puzzle is well made, but is difficult to the extent that it interferes with jigsaw puzzle enjoyment, I rate it at 3 stars (‚ÄúIt's okay‚Äù on the official Amazon scale).

title: Big, Fast Build‚ÄîBut It's Only a Tame Ferris Wheel Ride
text:
[[VIDEOID:5795137e2a23bd3d76a56d2b9446c889]] If you're already familiar with K'Nex building sets, this K'NEX THRILL RIDES-REVOLUTION FERRIS WHEEL is a simple, fast build. The Ferris wheel is big, but it doesn't require a lot of pieces. Also, much of the assembly involves building duplicate parts that combine to make the wheel and its swinging gondolas.

The set is recommended for age 7+, and that sounds reasonable (assuming that an adult provides some initial help with making the connections, and assists with lifting the wheel onto the axle). Each shape of piece is a different color, which detracts from the appearance of the finished Ferris wheel, but makes the construction simpler. There aren't many ‚Äúsnowflake‚Äù connections, which I usually have to puzzle over to get the right orientation. (K'Nex pieces are much harder to work with than LEGO pieces.) The instructions are reasonably clear. This set took me about 5 hours to build (from opening the box to completion, working at a leisurely pace).

Unfortunately, the finished ‚Äúthrill ride‚Äù isn't very thrilling. Like a full-sized amusement park ride, the Ferris wheel doesn't do much‚Äîit just goes around and around in a circle. Also, it does NOT have a variable speed control‚Äîyou cannot start, stop, or speed up the wheel gradually (like a real ride). Although the motor has a single speed, it does run in forward and reverse directions. The motor is powered by two AA batteries (not included).

For the Ferris wheel to turn properly, one edge of the inner wheel track must be settled into the groove on the ‚Äúgear wheel‚Äù attached to the motor. You can easily fiddle with the base to adjust things so that the track and groove always make good contact. Because it's sort of boring and lacks a variable speed control, I rate this K'Nex Ferris Wheel kit at 4 stars (‚ÄúI like it‚Äù on the official Amazon scale).

title: Challenging to Build, But Performs Really Well
text:
[[VIDEOID:8ec1360aa58e9f75263c785ff4853349]] [[VIDEOID:fe66008969573ae19b364dcc556f64ce]] This K'NEX EDUCATION STEM EXPLORATIONS: ROLLER COASTER BUILDING SET is challenging to build, but it's a satisfying building set. It's motorized, and it performs really well. It's fun to watch the chain pull the roller coaster car up to the top of the tower. And of course it's fun to watch the car do the curves and loops of the track by gravity when it's released.

It took me a couple of days, working off and on, to assemble this roller coaster. The K'NEX pieces are fiddly to join, and the drawings in the instruction booklet are hard to interpret if you're new to the K'NEX system. (The ‚Äúsnowflake‚Äù connectors are confusing; the rods must be inserted ‚Äújust so‚Äù; and the drawings sometimes change their directional perspective without warning.)

What I really loved about this set, is that the roller coaster car will often go around the loop more than once without any help. Three continuous loops is fairly common. Whether the car continues to loop by itself seems to depend on where the ‚Äúchain-grabber‚Äù underneath the car hits the chain‚Äîwhether it hits an opening in the chain or not. If you're aiming for continuous loops, it helps to hold the base down.

The K'NEX rods are thin, so the roller coaster support structure is kind of flimsy. However, the connections are tight enough that you can pick the whole structure up and move it without destroying it. A few connections may come loose, but they're easy to reconnect. The roller coaster is a large structure (30‚Äù wide, 16‚Äù deep, 25‚Äù high), so you need quite a bit of space to build and play with it.

The three experiments (one included in the box, two downloadable from the K'NEX web site) add to the educational value of this building set. The first experiment suggests adding different amounts of weight to the car to test how added mass affects the car's ability to run the loops. For the second and third experiments, you rebuild the coaster into a long gravity ramp, and then into a half pipe, to learn more about how a car behaves on a straight or U-shaped track. Neither of these builds makes use of the motor, which is why the roller coaster build is far and away the best.

When you open the box, keep the contents of each bag together, more or less. You'll save time if you don't dump all of the pieces out in a big pile on the tabletop. The pieces that are the same type are grouped together in the plastic bags‚Äîchain links, rods of certain lengths, red connectors, blue connectors, spacers, etc.

When I'm assembling a big project like this one, with a lot of pieces, I use disposable plastic dinner and salad plates to hold the similar, or the same-colored, parts. A nice thing about this K'NEX set is that each different type of connector is a different color (the orange connectors are different from the yellow connectors, and so on), so it's enough to check the color of the piece when you're following the instructions.

title: Limited Educational Value; Booklet Encourages Creativity by Omitting Step-by-Step Assembly Instructions
text:
The great strength--and weakness--of this CREATIVITY FOR KIDS SPARK!LAB SMITHSONIAN "INVENT A MOTORIZED ROBOT" MODEL KIT is that there are NO step-by-step instructions for building even one simple model robot. The idea of the kit is that a kid will figure out how to use the included parts to assemble a heavy paper robot of her/his own design. The included booklet only gives general hints on how to use the parts.

The illustrations on the box give further hints for assembling the parts into different-looking robots. The parts include: foam gears; plastic soda straws; bendable wire; gold metallic tape; glue; paper fasteners; punch-out, foldable, printed paper robot body parts; a motor wired to a pair of LED lights and a battery box; decorative stickers; and other items.

The box shows a complete inventory of the parts, except that it doesn't make it clear that the boxy robot body parts are only made of lightweight paper, and that they arrive in flat sheets (although the punch-out body parts do have score lines to help with folding them into three-dimensional components). For some reason, the batteries for powering the motor (two AA alkaline batteries) are NOT included.

For the right child, this may be a fun toy. It is relatively inexpensive (about $20 on Amazon) for a building toy. However, I think that many children would be as baffled as I was by this building set. How do you attach the gear wheels? Do you use the plastic straws for axles? If so, how do you attach the axles to the robot body so that they will turn? Where should I place the motor? What, if anything, will the motor power besides the big gear wheels?

Many of the included parts are merely decorative, and struck me as being a waste of time. I don't know whether the motor will power anything besides wheels (e.g., robot arms), but I do know that the motor's usefulness is severely limited by the very short length of wire between it and the battery box. The two LED lights are attached to the battery box with short wires, too, so they always have to be placed close to the motor. The lightweight paper components will not stand up to being taken apart and reassembled into different configurations--at least not very often.

Overall, I don't think this kit will teach anything about robotics. It will teach that gears attached to a motor will turn when the motor is turned on; and it will teach that you can rearrange decorative items to make robots that look different. Because of its limited educational value and lack of instructions that make the assembly task fun all by itself, I rate this building toy at 2 stars ("I don't like it" on the official Amazon scale).

title: Construction Pieces Are Hard to Assemble/Disassemble for Building Your Own Layout Designs
text:
[[VIDEOID:e0353531352173525aa3b993e4d37802]]This LIONEL MEGA TRACKS (CORKSCREW CHAOS GREEN ENGINE) playset was a big disappointment, even though I love model train layouts, Hot Wheels track sets, and LEGO building kits. What it is, is a car (like a train engine) that runs around a circular track that you can configure in different ways (assuming you have the extra parts for tracks, supports, and connectors). Like a model train set, it takes up a large amount of floor space.

The remote-controlled car charges in minutes, the car responds quickly to the pistol-grip remote, and the car doesn't jump the track easily. (A charger for the car is included, but you will need to buy a 9-volt battery for the remote.) However, the car only runs around and around the loop, so the real fun lies in building new and different track configurations.

Unfortunately, building a new configuration is not easy, because the construction pieces are very hard to put together and take apart. The square beam and clamp ends, and the gear-like round connector ends, take some force to insert in the joining spaces. After they're inserted, they can only be removed by exerting more force as you rock them back and forth slowly out of the joining spaces. In contrast, the track connectors are easy to attach (by snapping them shut), but you need a pry tool (a U.S. quarter or a flat screwdriver) to get those track connectors open again.

I made a lot of mistakes during the first setup (which took me 1-1/2 hours). I got a lot of practice at taking the parts apart, and my fingers hurt afterwards. (I'm really not looking forward to taking my set apart for storage.)

The assembly instructions leave a LOT to be desired. The tiny drawings don't clearly show the positioning of various connectors that can be inserted in more than one orientation, or the subtle differences between similar parts (e.g., the ‚ÄúB‚Äù and ‚ÄúC‚Äù track connectors). There is also a mistake in one diagram, which labels a part ‚ÄúI‚Äù as a part ‚ÄúH‚Äù.

Because the construction parts are so difficult to put together and take apart, and the playset is boring unless you can fool around with different track configurations, I rate this LIONEL MEGA TRACKS toy at 3 stars (‚ÄúIt's okay‚Äù on the official Amazon scale). Note that you can buy this set with either a red engine or a green engine‚Äîif you buy one of each, you can build a larger layout and you can race or crash the cars, because the red and green remote controllers operate on different frequencies.

title: Budget-Priced Introduction to String Art Craft
text:
This CRAFT-TASTIC 3D STRING ART KIT provides an inexpensive (about $6.25 on Amazon) introduction to the string art craft. It includes a snap-together plastic frame, plenty of colored embroidery floss for string, and reasonably clear instructions. The box says it's for ages 8 and up, which seems about right. (Adult help might be needed to assemble the frame, which requires the pegs to be properly oriented upwards or downwards for everything to snap together tightly.)

There is some artistic creativity involved with this kit, as there are no stringing diagrams to follow. Instead, the instructions say to knot your string to a peg in the frame, and then "wrap the thread from a peg in one (upper) heart to a peg on the other side (the lower heart)." This is simple enough, but it's up to you to choose the pegs so that you get an eye-pleasing criss-crossing of the thread.

Personally, I don't care for the color combinations: bright blue small inside heart, purple edge for the large outside heart, yellow front of large outside heart, pink back of large outside heart. When you're finished with all the stringing, you can set the big heart up on a little plastic stand.

A small child might enjoy this project a lot. However, being an adult, I was bored by the time I'd finished the small blue heart. Because this kit persuaded me that I don't care for the string art craft, I rate it at 3 stars ("It's okay" on the official Amazon scale). However, the budget price probably makes it a reasonable purchase if the intent is to keep a small child busy.

title: Great Action Figures, But Small Scale Makes Assembly More Difficult
text:
This MEGA BLOKS CALL OF DUTY ANTI-AIRCRAFT VEHICLE has a lot of interesting detail, but it's quite a bit smaller than I expected. The small size requires small blocks, and to stay in scale the soldiers' accessories (e.g., the hand grenade, the pockets, the belts) get really tiny. Thus the assembly is more difficult than for other building toys with similar numbers of pieces.

The camouflage coloring on most of the blocks also slowed my assembly down, because it makes the blocks harder to see and identify. (But of course that's what camouflage is supposed to do, and you want camouflage in a military-themed building toy!) The soldiers are indeed "superposable" action figures, per the claim on the box. The figures bend at the knees and elbows; and the head, torso, arms and legs all attach with ball joints, so they can move in many directions.

The instruction booklet (4-3/4" x 8-1/8") is pretty good, though some of the pages have a few too many of the assembly steps combined. It's easy to make mistakes when blocks are added on the top and the bottom of other blocks in a single step.

Because I found the toy overly difficult to assemble on account of the small size, I rate it at 4 stars ("I like it" on the official Amazon scale).

title: Rebuilds Into Four Different Gravity-Defying Configurations; Uses Minimal Floor Space
text:
This HOT WHEELS TRACK BUILDER SYSTEM STUNT KIT is one of the best "stunt kits" yet, because it can be set up in any of four (4) different gravity-defying configurations. You build a basic "stunt base", then choose the build that suits your numbered experience level: High Jump (1), Criss Cross (2), Long Jump (3), or The Drop (4). If you tire of one of the builds, you can easily take it apart and rebuild it into a different one. (The stunt pictured on the box is the High Jump.)

Because I'm experienced with the Track Builder System, I chose to build the Long Jump. (I passed on The Drop for now, because it requires a tabletop as well as floor space for the setup.) This is a high-performance stunt--you load a car into the rubber-band-powered launcher, hit the launcher release disk hard, and send the car up a ramp, around a loop-de-loop, over a wide gap to a ramp landing, and then down the track to exit the stunt into the rest of your Track Builder layout. You can use the "measuring stick" to measure and lengthen the gap (the distance to the ramp), once you master the launching technique needed to send the car through the entire stunt to a successful completion.

Unfortunately, this stunt kit is also one of the most difficult to build. The Hot Wheels instructions are always a bit confusing--the drawings are three-dimensional, but they lack the dimensional accuracy of LEGO drawings. The parts are shown in the instructions in their actual plastic colors, which helps, but the drawings don't always make it easy to identify the shapes of the parts or to see exactly how they go together. However, the Building Instructions and parts for this kit have a feature I don't remember seeing before: letters (A, B, C, etc.) molded into the parts, so you can match the letters (A to A; B to B: etc.) to connect the parts. This, too, helps with the building stage. (Always remember that if you can't get the car to complete the stunt--no matter how hard you try--you probably made a mistake in the build.)

The parts in the "stunt base" (see my first photo below) click together very tightly, and more or less permanently. I was unable to pry the parts apart, even using workshop tools. As a result, the assembled stunt kit cannot be taken completely apart for flat storage in the original box.

This stunt kit comes with only one Hot Wheels car, and you will need at least one more car to fully play with it. All four configurations have suggestions for using two cars (crashing at track crossings, comparing speeds, etc.). The kit has two (2) extremely powerful 4-speed launchers--I love these! The launchers are the best I've ever seen. (They are already set up when you take them out of the box--don't fool with the rubber bands.) Another new wrinkle in this Stunt Kit is that you can use the retail box itself to add interest and difficulty to your larger Track Builder System layout. There are printed ramps and "fire pits" that can be pushed up and locked together to make a platform with more obstacles for the cars.

This is an excellent choice for any Track Builder System layout, because of its versatility, economical use of floor space, and low price (about $24 on Amazon). The only drawback is that it's harder to build than most Hot Wheels stunts.

title: Useful for Home Hand Therapy
text:
This HAPE COLOR AND SHAPE SORTER is a high-quality, durable wooden toy that performs exactly as expected, helping with the development of fine motor skills.

I purchased this set for my husband to use in occupational therapy, in conjunction with a Saebo glove, for the purpose of restoring some use to his stroke-damaged hand. It's a good, inexpensive set for home-use purposes. It provides visual interest and variety, along with a genuine but attainable challenge.

Hape also makes a "designing" set with very small pegs ([[ASIN:B0002HYEQW HABA Color Peg, Color Pictures Game]]) that I hope my husband will be able to use eventually, as his hand improves. It is another very well-made wooden pegboard set.

title: Holes in Foam Base Close Up, Making Peg Insertion Difficult
text:
This PEGBOARD SET WITH PATTERN CARD comes with lots of big, colorful, stackable pegs, but the foam base is something of a disaster. Out of the box, the holes are too small for the pegs, so the instructions say to "condition" the base by inserting the pegs all the way through the holes and leaving them there overnight. This does enlarge the holes in the foam base, but the holes still want to close up. This makes the pegs difficult to insert into the base for play.

I purchased this set for my husband to use for occupational therapy at home, in conjunction with a Saebo glove, to help restore functionality to his stroke-damaged hand. Unfortunately, the set is useless for this purpose, because of the effort it takes to insert the pegs (even if you have full use of both hands). I think it would be equally difficult for a child to use this set, at least until the foam base becomes well-worn so that the peg holes will stop closing up.

A couple of pegboard sets that do work for my husband's hand therapy are the [[ASIN:B0009K30YY Learning Resources Stacking Shapes Peg Board]], and the [[ASIN:B008E18S60 Hape Color and Shape Sorter]]. Because of its disappointing foam base, I rate the Pegboard Set With Pattern Card at 2 stars ("I don't like it" on the official Amazon scale).

title: Versatile Set Works for Hand Therapy at Home
text:
This LEARNING RESOURCES STACKING SHAPES PEG BOARD is a good quality product. It has lots of brightly colored, stackable pegs in five shapes (star, square, circle, triangle, hexagon). Importantly, it has a plastic base with stable holes that are sized to easily accept the pegs. (This means it is a far better choice than the [[ASIN:B011VSK1WQ Peg Board Set with Pattern Card]], which has a foam base with holes that close up so it's hard to insert the pegs.) In this set, the different shapes can be placed in any hole, and the different shapes can be interchangeably stacked.

I purchased this set for my husband to use in occupational therapy, in conjunction with a Saebo glove, for the purpose of restoring some use to his stroke-damaged hand. It's a good, inexpensive set for home-use OT purposes. It provides visual interest and variety, along with a genuine but attainable challenge.

title: Perfect Pairing for LEGO Wall-E Display
text:
Because Wall-E's sharing his treasures with Eve (in the movie) was so charming, I wanted a Rubik's Cube for my LEGO Wall-E model. As you can see from my photo, this WORLD'S SMALLEST RUBIK'S CUBE is the perfect size!

This is a working Rubik's Cube, although the squares turn fairly hard, so it's not good for speed solving. It requires careful handling to avoid breakage, but it's ideal for my display.

title: Giant Troll, Clubless (From Troll Assault Wagon Set)
text:
This LEGO CASTLE TROLL (SAND GREEN) is a clubless giant troll (the one from the Troll Assault Wagon set (7038), I think). It has white spikes and horns, and is about three times the size of a regular LEGO minifigure. The body and head are in one piece; the arms, hands, and horns are separate. IMO, it looks exactly the way a troll should look--especially the green color!

Mine (purchased from TheToyExplorer) came complete, in a sealed plastic "body bag", along with a recloseable plastic bag containing the additional parts.

title: Standalone Set Launches Big-Wheeled Truck or Two Regular Cars at Chomping Dragon
text:
[[VIDEOID:9dfca535e4cfc492b8a727bc7728e93b]] Of all my many Hot Wheels sets and stunts, this HOT WHEELS MONSTER JAM DRAGON BUILDUP set is my least favorite. It's a one-trick show--you hit the launcher, and your big-wheeled truck is either "chomped" by the dragon, or the truck clears the dragon's mouth, dislodges the dragon's head (sometimes), and knocks the championship cup off the dragon's tail. The outcome is strictly a matter of how hard you hit the launcher. After about five minutes, I was tired of playing with this setup.

Kids may like the three (3) big-wheeled trucks that come with this set. For variations in play, the dragon element has two connectors for the launch ramp. The first connector aims the truck at the dragon's mouth and tail; the second connector aims the truck at the dragon's tail. Also, you can buy a second Dragon Buildup set, and connect the ramp from that set to your original dragon element, to be able to launch two big-wheeled trucks from different directions at the same time. (I can't see this as being fun enough to justify purchasing a second set.) Finally, the launcher will launch two standard Hot Wheels cars (not included), as well as one big-wheeled truck. (It is kind of fun to launch two cars at once.)

This set does NOT connect to other Hot Wheels layouts. It's a standalone. The set took me about 10 minutes to assemble, and about 15 minutes to add the stickers. The stickers are worth the trouble, because they include the dragon's teeth, and two mean red dragon's eyes. There is also a sticker for fans sitting on bleachers to watch the action.

Because Hot Wheels Monster Jam Dragon Buildup is kind of boring and doesn't connect to other layouts, I rate it at 3 stars ("It's okay" on the official Amazon scale).

title: Not Fun, Not Educational--Another Bad Toy Marketed for Girls
text:
[[VIDEOID:a7abc24222a8ac6ac6e109fd1d38813d]] This COOL BAKER CHOCOLATE TREATS MAKER is one of the worst toys marketed for girls that I've ever encountered. One, it isn't fun (too many "wait several minutes" steps, and needs a lot of adult help). Two, there is no suitable chocolate included in the box. Three, it's extremely hard to create the candies as shown in the advertising (even though you're given the molds). Four, it cannot be taken apart (for flat storage) once it has been assembled. Five, it's hand-washable and even requires a brush for cleaning the crevices.

MELTING CHOCOLATE. Much to my surprise, this toy DOES melt chocolate with hot tap water alone. (At least if your household has very hot tap water like mine does.) You fill the pink warming tank (which has a separator that can be added for melting different chocolate colors at the same time) with hot water. Then it takes 5-10 minutes, per the instructions, to melt the chocolate (even if you chop and stir with the spatula as you wait). If you must actually heat the water for the tank, you must keep the water under a maximum 111 degrees Fahrenheit (well below boiling or simmering), because that is all that the plastic tank can handle. The instructions warn that an adult should perform the task of filling the chocolate-warming tank.

Different kinds of chocolate do take different amounts of time to melt. My idea of using butterscotch chips, for the caramel color, turned out to be a bad one. Butterscotch chips take much longer than milk chocolate chips or white-melting-chocolate disks, and the melted butterscotch isn't very workable even after it's melted. I was unable to find any colored chocolate disks (as shown in the advertising) for melting, but maybe these are available online or in cooking specialty stores.

CREATING TWO-COLOR CANDIES. The 10-minute wait for melting isn't too bad. While you're waiting, you can oil your candy molds. If you want to create two-color chocolates, you must "paint" the details (owl eyes, gift package ribbon, central heart) into the molds with your first color, and then harden the details in the freezer for another 5 minutes. Trying to paint in the details was a disaster for me! Even though I read the instructions, I couldn't see what I needed to do to add the details and get well-defined owl eyes, or anything else.

After you harden the details, you fill the molds with the rest of your chocolate, snap the molds shut, and wipe off any oozing chocolate. You click each mold into the spinner thingy, and spin it for about 1 minute, before putting the mold into the freezer for a final 15 minutes to harden the candy. I don't know what the spinning is for--maybe it helps eliminate air bubbles--but I do know that spinning isn't fun. It's just boring.

After 15 minutes of freezing, you can unmold your chocolates fairly easily. They will probably have edges that need to be knocked off, because the chocolate oozes onto the flat parts of the mold when the mold is snapped shut.

AMOUNT OF CHOCOLATE NEEDED. An unpleasant surprise for me, was that a warming tray full of melted chocolate was NOT enough to fill all three candy molds. It was only enough to fill 1 to 1-1/2 candy molds. I had to melt chocolate in the largest section of the warming tank TWICE more to fill all three molds. (And being an adult, I didn't spill or waste any melted chocolate to speak of.)

GIFT TAGS AND BAGS. The full toy kit includes a spinner thingy, three candy molds, three tools (a two-ended scoop, a "paintbrush" for details, a useful spatula), some small plastic gift bags, and a sheet of gift stickers. The gift tags and bags are a nice idea, but you will have to practice with the molds if you want to create giftable candies. The whole process is, of course, very inefficient, and practicing will require a lot of melting of chocolate and washing of molds. It took me a couple of hours to go through everything for the first time.

ASSEMBLY. Probably the best thing about this toy is that it snaps together easily, and assembles into a solid "spinner" device. However, the snap-together parts expand behind the openings they're pushed through (sort of like toggle bolts). This means that the parts cannot be pulled apart again, for flat storage, once they've been connected. (I couldn't pry them apart with a screwdriver.) This is a space-hogging toy.

CLEANING. The parts of the toy are hand washable only. Chocolate sticks in the crevices of the molds and the chocolate-warming tank, and doesn't come out with soaking, so that a dish brush is required for cleaning.

SUMMATION. This toy will allow a parent and child to create candies from melted chocolate, but there is little educational value. Making candies this way bears no relationship to how candy is ordinarily made in the home kitchen. Also, making candies this way isn't fun. Most of the process involves waiting for chocolate to melt or waiting for chocolate to harden in the freezer. It's very difficult to fill the molds with the precision needed to create candies that resemble the ones shown on the box. Thus the finished candies are likely to be disappointing. The finished candies taste like what they're made of--melted and hardened chocolate chips.

Because this toy does actually melt chocolate chips or melting chocolate disks, and allow them to be molded into candies, as advertised, I rate it, rather generously, at 2 stars ("I don't like it" on the official Amazon scale).

title: Great Fun for Adult, But May Not Sustain Child's Interest
text:
This MATCHBOX DINO TRAPPER TRAILER toy is great fun for me, as an adult. I love the growling T-Rex sound effects, the glowing red eyes, and the whole operation of shooting a dart and then loading the sleeping dino onto the trailer. It is quite easy to hit the T-Rex in the chest with a dart, to put him to sleep. For the loading, you have to collar the T-Rex, attach him to the truck's winch, crank the winch to pull him onto the trailer, and then secure the load with a chain.

A couple of reservations I have: (1) I'm not sure how long this toy will sustain a child's interest; and (2) I think that attaching the rubbery collar and chain will require more strength and dexterity than a small child's hands are likely to possess. However, the T-Rex is fun to activate and move around, and the trapper's truck is a big, solid, detailed toy--a great truck for playing with by itself. The darts are easily aimed, travel just far enough to be retrieved without effort, and have padded tips that are unlikely to do any damage to anyone who is hit by one.

Getting the T-Rex and trapper's truck out of the box is a bit of a challenge. There are posts that need to be rotated from the underside of the cardboard, a string to cut, some clamshell packaging (for the darts), and a rubber band around the truck's wheel that secures the winch. A small child would definitely need help unpacking this toy.

Note that this is a "Matchbox" toy, but not a matchbox-sized toy. It is a very large toy.

I genuinely love the Dino Trapper Trailer, and want to keep it for myself! It will be given to a child, though--eventually.

title: Time-Consuming, Fiddly Build; Fun Except That Spiral-Lift Gears Disengage Easily
text:
I love building toys, perpetual motion machines, and Rube Goldberg inventions, so of course I like this MARBLE MANIA ZOOMERANG BUILDING KIT. It's not as much fun as it ought to be, though.

First, it's quite fiddly to put together. The black "universal" connectors must be oriented correctly (with holes outward) whenever they support ramp clips. The purple tower pieces come in several sizes, and choosing a wrong size piece will create a tower that's the wrong height so that the ramps will slant incorrectly. The clear tube surrounding the orange spiral lifter has a light gray connector at the bottom that must be placed "just so" or the marbles won't be able to enter the tube.

Second, playing with the setup is constantly interrupted because cranking the spiral lift causes the gears to disconnect frequently.
