I found that I could achieve fairly constant motion if I held the support piece for the lower gear (the green one) down with my hand against the black (gridded) base, but even then the gears would unexpectedly disengage--just when I was beginning to enjoy the perpetual motion rhythm.

The "Rube Goldberg" aspect of the toy is a lot of fun. The marbles climb to the top of the spiral, move quickly down the ramps, and circle around or drop straight through the blue funnel to begin their journey anew. The spiral lifter will hold as many as eight marbles--the building kit comes with three marbles--and you can get more marbles going through if you can solve the problem of the disengaging gears. The marbles occasionally jump the track, but not often.

The assembly instructions aren't as clear as LEGO instructions, but they're not very hard to follow. The black universal connections have a little red dot in front of them when they need to be oriented with the holes forward (see my customer photo). The parts are reasonably well made. One of my connector pieces was flawed, but it worked all right as a support piece (see my customer photo). The $19.99 price seemed about right for this toy.

This kit did in fact require a couple of hours for assembly. Usually I can assemble a structure with the equivalent number of pieces much faster. The black universal connector pieces in particular were uncomfortable to handle.

I believe that this kit can be combined with other TechnoGears Marble Mania kits to create a more complex marble maze. However, I wasn't interested in building onto this particular kit, because of the problem with the spiral crank and the disengaging gears. I rate MARBLE MANIA ZOOMERANG at 4 stars ("I like it" on the official Amazon scale).

title: Adds Color, Motion to Hot Wheels Track Builder Set
text:
[[VIDEOID:794a93ea445d6873412d11a47fb6c604]]This HOT WHEELS FAN MAN ACCESSORY is a fun addition to any Hot Wheels Track Builder set. It adds color and motion, but not a lot of car-triggered action. When a car hits the lever that supposedly "flattens" the Fan Man, he pops right back up, because the trigger doesn't turn off the fan or the air flow that keeps him aloft. (This is probably a good thing, because it means that the accessory doesn't need constant resetting.)

The Fan Man accessory is easy to assemble. It requires two alkaline C batteries (not included) to run the fan. You use a Phillips screwdriver to open the battery case and insert the batteries. Then you pop the fan blade onto the blue base. Then you click the red fan guard and Fan Man assembly onto the blue base. Then you click the orange "track holder" onto the side of the blue base. And you're done!

The red switch turns the fan on and off. You run a section of orange Track Builder track through the orange track holder (in any layout). When a car comes down the track and hits the gray lever (from one direction only), the Fan Man is temporarily flattened.

My Fan Man came with a crease under one arm (from the way it was packed) but the crease smoothed out some when I blotted it carefully with water. It will probably iron out with low heat, but I'm not going to try this, because of the danger of melting the little guy. The crease makes no difference whatever when the Fan Man is twisting and waving his arms while the fan is turned on.

title: Challenger Puzzle Tests Skills of Expert Jigsawer
text:
[[VIDEOID:51e7617cadf31bd8d128cb7d9c7b5e17]]It's hard to believe that a mere 1000-piece jigsaw puzzle can be so difficult! The RAVENSBURGER TITANIC PUZZLE is a genuine challenger--a puzzle that's interesting to assemble as a test of an expert jigsawer's skill, but one that's NOT fun to put together, because it's so very, very difficult. Even the borders are difficult, and it's a temptation to quit altogether when the "easy" parts are completed, and only the top one-third with the dark blue, starry sky remains.

The puzzle painting captures the very essence of the Titanic's last night, showing the doomed ocean liner steaming ahead at top speed on a clear, starry night--through a field of ice, toward the disaster that awaits her. The dark blues of the sky, the stars in the Milky Way, and the reflections of the ship's lights on the water are so peaceful and beautiful!

This puzzle would be a terrible choice for family entertainment, because the deep-blue sky pieces (in particular) are nearly impossible to distinguish by their colors or starry patterning. The sky pieces must be laboriously assembled by closely examining the shapes (total number of tabs, large/small tab combinations, left/right offsets for tabs, etc.), and this is a task for a dedicated jigsawer working alone.

Fortunately, it's not easy to make mistakes, because this is a high-quality Ravensburger puzzle with individual pieces that click softly into place. This makes the assembly job a little bit easier. (For an equally difficult jigsaw puzzle, one with pieces so similarly shaped that you CAN make mistakes, try the [[ASIN:B00B4RQU5C Tintin Rocket Puzzle]], if you can find one.)

title: Cars Complete Their Runs Flawlessly; Versatile Design With Many Options for Addition to Existing Track Layout
text:
This HOT WHEELS TRACK BUILDER SPIRAL STACK-UP set is a terrific choice for expanding an existing Hot Wheels track layout, as long as you have a fair amount of floor or table space. It's a really large stunt that's about five feet long when it's assembled according to the boxed instructions (though the launcher ramps can be rearranged, using two towers instead of one, to use less space).

The way this set works, is that the first car launched from the top of the tower launches two more cars (not included with the set) as it speeds down the ramp, then triggers a release that dumps a car off the second level of the "box" located at the end of the double ramp, until it finally exits the stunt through the lower level of the "box". The second car that is launched (by the first car) speeds down a long ramp that is connected near the top of the tower, and exits the stunt. The third car that is launched travels down a short ramp and stops on the second level of the exit "box", waiting to for the first car to dump it.

There's a lot of action that makes me smile in this track builder set. Also, the two cars that actually exit the setup have a lot of momentum left that will carry them elsewhere in a well-designed layout. One of the best things about this setup is that all three cars usually complete the entire run flawlessly, without jumping the track or losing momentum or stopping too soon. The "Nitrium" car that comes with the set is a fairly heavy one, because the set works best with a weighty car starting in the top position.

For me, this Hot Wheels playset was a little more challenging to assemble than others that I've set up. As always, the key thing is to identify your parts correctly, and to keep looking until you find the right place to make a connection if you don't understand the instructions right away. The color-coding of the plastic parts helped me with one confusing part--the set has two red launcher arms that attach to a yellow base, and one gray launcher lever that attaches to a gray base. In my customer photos, there are three cars loaded into the set--the orange/white car at the very top is the included Nitrium car.

title: New Favorite Hot Wheels Stunt Accessory
text:
This HOT WHEELS SHIFTERS COLOR SPLASH SCIENCE LAB PLAYSET is my new favorite Hot Wheels Stunt accessory! It's messy, because the car splashes water when it lands in a pool, but it's fun. You load the tank at the top with ice water, and the pool at the end of the track with hot water, and the included Color-Shifter car will change color when it comes in contact with either the hot or the cold water (dark to light color, or vice versa).

My Color-Shifter car needs to park underneath the cold waterfall (below the tank) or the cold spray (the pipe extending from the water tank) for a little while in order to change color, but there are moveable barriers that allow parking. The Color-Shifter car changes color instantly when it lands in the hot pool. At room temperature, the car retains its dark, light, or partially-shifted color (see my customer photos).

A feature that I really like, is that when you launch one car, it triggers the release of a second car if you have placed a second car under the spray pipe, so that the two cars will exit the stunt playset simultaneously (at the bottom on the ramps at the left and the right). You can adjust how the launched car will exit--you can set a ramp in the middle to either crash the car into the hot-water pool or allow the car to jump the pool and continue down the track to the exit. Because the two exit ramps can be connected to other tracks, you can incorporate this messy water stunt playset into a larger Hot Wheels layout!

The Color-Shifter cars apparently vary from playset to playset. My playset came with a Nitro Doorslammer (dark green with cold water, light green with warm water). Additional Color-Shifter cars (e.g., [[ASIN:B00IVP9UHA 24/SEVEN]]) are available from Amazon, but a regular Hot Wheels car that weighs about the same as the included car works fine. The playset instructions caution that all Hot Wheels/Hot Wheels Color-Shifter cars may not work in every playset. This playset's box has "City" printed on the front, so I would guess that all Color-Shifter cars in the "City" series will work with it.

Some reviewers have complained that the cars won't stay on the tracks, but I didn't have this problem. The launcher has three tension settings, and my cars negotiated the tracks perfectly as long as I launched them with the first or second tension setting. The track needs to be snapped together firmly for it to work. The assembly instructions are easy to follow, although there are some tricky parts.

title: Decorative, Irresistibly Cute Train Toy!
text:
This MANHATTAN TOY STACK AND PULL TRAIN is irresistibly cute! It's ready to play with, right out of the box--the three wooden train cars are already assembled, and the wooden stacking blocks are loose so you can immediately begin fitting them onto the poles that "attach" them to the cars. The toy is well-made, all-wooden, and rolls smoothly across my living room carpet with the lightest of tugs on the woven pull cord.

There are only a few ways to fit all of the stacking blocks squarely onto the train cars--the blocks with curved sides (that fit with the cylinder-shaped blocks) align with the diagonally cut blocks, but their plain sides don't sit flat on the cars. I found myself looking at the picture on the box, to get all the blocks loaded onto the cars in the best possible arrangement--and had to laugh at myself! No small child would be the least bit bothered by stacking his or her blocks in a way that leaves spaces between the blocks.

I love the bright colors of these blocks, and the cheerful expressions of the farmer, the cow, and the pig. The colors harmonize no matter how the blocks are arranged, and the painted triangles, dots, and curlicues add extra variety to the possible building-block combinations. A detail that I particularly like, is the pair of yellow circles for headlights that appear on an edge of the green block that is used to represent the train or tractor engine. This is an extremely well-thought-out toy.

Also, this is a marvelously decorative toy. I think it will look great on a shelf in a child's room, long after the child has outgrown playing with it. Best of all, it's a toy that makes me smile when I look at it.

title: Fast, Satisfying Assembly; Fun "Augmented Reality" Feature
text:
[[VIDEOID:8d5da775f41ae0104b94b3b2e1f31605]] The Ravensburger COLORFUL ACTIVITY AT TIMES SQUARE jigsaw puzzle is a lot of fun to assemble. There are 1000 pieces, but the puzzle goes together fast, because of the many vertical lines (e.g., buildings, billboards), written advertising messages (e.g., Kodak, Marriott), and distinctive color areas (e.g., beer bottle, taxicabs, window patterns). It took me two days to complete. (I'm admittedly rather obsessed once I get started on a jigsaw puzzle.)

The "augmented reality" add-on is fun to play with. You download the free "AR Puzzle" app (available only for iPhone 3GS, 4, 4S; or iPad 2, 3) from iTunes; start the app; select your puzzle; and choose "360 degrees" or "facts". You then activate the augmented reality display by aiming your iPhone or iPad camera at the finished puzzle (or at the complete full-color puzzle photo that's packed in the box).

If you choose "360 degrees", your device will display a view of Times Square. The view changes as you turn yourself and your device around in a circle, so that the app seems to put you right there in the middle of the Times Square scene. If you choose "facts", you can click on the "i" balloons as they come up over your puzzle, and get factoid displays. (You must be patient and sweep over the puzzle photo to get the fact balloons). My accompanying video slide show shows what you can expect from the augmented reality app on an iPad2.

My only complaint about this puzzle is that the photos of Times Square don't seem to be very current, judging from the taxicabs and the things being advertised on the billboards. However, it's a very satisfying puzzle to assemble, and the add-on feature is interesting and easy to use. I thoroughly enjoyed every minute I spent playing with this.

title: Challenger Jigsaw--Almost Too Difficult to Be Fun
text:
You wouldn't know it from the picture, but CAFE TERRACE AT NIGHT is an extremely difficult jigsaw puzzle. If you decide to try it, you won't need another jigsaw to work on for quite a while!

With any 1500-piece jigsaw, you have to work by general color areas. After rough sorting, I had the fewest pieces in deep orange, so I started with them. Because they also had the cafe tables and people, I thought they'd go together quickly. Wrong, wrong, wrong! Progress was so slow, I didn't want to work on the puzzle at all (even though I love doing jigsaw puzzles). It took me about 5 weeks--working on and off (mostly off)--to finish the orange part. Now I'm working on the cobblestones, and the puzzle is going faster--because I've got the hang of Van Gogh's painting style--but it's still going much more slowly than is usual for me.

Aside from the difficulty, another problem with this puzzle is that it's very tall. Because it's taller than my work table is wide, my original plan was to work the puzzle sideways on the work table. I soon discovered that the puzzle is far too difficult to be assembled that way. After a time, I turned the puzzle around so that it would be facing me straight on, and separated the top part of the puzzle border (the part that wouldn't fit on the table) to work it later as a separate puzzle section. When both the main section and the top section are finished, I'll join them briefly for a photo session.

CAFE TERRACE AT NIGHT is a puzzle that only an expert, addicted, jigsaw puzzler will enjoy--primarily for the challenge. Like all Ravensburger puzzles, it is manufactured to very high standards. The pieces are made of fairly thick cardboard, and they are perfectly cut, so that the pieces slip effortlessly into place when you have the right ones. However, because the puzzle is almost too difficult to be fun, even as an extreme jigsaw challenge, I rate it at 4 stars ("I like it" on the official Amazon scale).

title: Irregularly-Shaped Pieces Make "Hatley Park" Especially Challenging
text:
[[VIDEOID:moMO0O00W4S41F]]This Springbok "Hatley Park" jigsaw puzzle was much more difficult than I expected, even for a 1000-piece puzzle. The large areas of red tree leaves (at the top) and fallen leaves along the pathway (at the bottom) each have a lot of similarly colored pieces that take patience to sort. Also, the individual puzzle pieces (no two the same) are cut so that the pieces don't form regular rows and columns across the entire puzzle (unlike the cut of Ravensburger puzzles).

As you put "Hatley Park" together, you must hunt for specific pieces that have quite unusual and irregular sizes and shapes. Often you must put two pieces together to be able to see the shape of the third piece, which interlocks with both. Even the straight-edged border of this puzzle is something of a challenge! As you can see from the video slide show that accompanies this review, some of the smaller border pieces don't look like border pieces at all.

If you enjoy working difficult jigsaw puzzles, and like the puzzle photo (as I do), then you ought to have fun assembling "Hatley Park" even though it takes some extra effort. Like all Springbok puzzles, "Hatley Park" is a high-quality, carefully-manufactured jigsaw puzzle that has a well-thought-out overall design.

title: Not for Beginners or the Faint of Heart!
text:
This NEUSCHWANSTEIN CASTLE XXL puzzle is not for beginners, or for the faint of heart! Any 2000-piece Ravensburger puzzle is difficult, simply because of the number of pieces, but this puzzle is probably above average in difficulty.

The puzzle measures 52" wide by 24" high--it's a panoramic puzzle--so make sure you have cleared a wide space for it. The XXL size means that the fine photo details are spread over more than one puzzle piece, and this increases the difficulty. The puzzle is easiest to assemble if you stand over it as you go, so that you can see the bigger, overall picture.

Ravensburger puzzles always have color areas to help you. That's true of this puzzle, but the sky--there's lots of it!-- has less color variation than usual. The border pieces are easy to find and assemble, but when you start on the remaining puzzle, it really dawns on you what a challenging task you have undertaken. There are piles of dark blue, light blue, autumn-colored, and mostly-white pieces that look very much alike. For me, the hardest area was the lower left side, with all of the blue trees; and the big snow-covered tree at the right was far more difficult than I expected. The castle was easy, and the autumn-colored trees were easier than you would think from looking at the box photo.

Despite its difficulty, this puzzle was a pleasure to work. The photo is just so beautiful! Working at a comfortable pace (one to several hours at a stretch, but not every day), I needed about a month to finish this one. As usual, I found the Ravensburger craftsmanship to be extraordinary--the pieces fit together so nicely that mistakes were few and far between. I highly recommend this puzzle for expert (addicted) jigsaw puzzle enthusiasts.

title: Well-Made Puzzle, Difficult But Totally Enjoyable
text:
Ravensburger puzzles are so well-made, they are always a pleasure to put together. The pieces slip into place easily if they're correct, and only rarely do two similarly colored pieces seem to fit. With Ravensburger puzzles, my mistakes are minimal.

I love to work difficult jigsaw puzzles, and assembling this LOFOTON, NORWAY puzzle was totally enjoyable. The picture divides by color into several main areas (mountain, mountain range, dark sky, light sky, water, buildings, rocky outcropping, green trees), and none of the areas have a huge number of pieces. If you take the time to sort the pieces, you can make quick work of this big, 1000-piece puzzle. The hardest area is the green in the bottom right corner--that was a bit of a challenge, because the pieces are dark and have little or no photo detail!

The "augmented reality" portion of this puzzle is fairly simple. After you download the "AR Puzzle" app from the iTunes store (you may have to Google it to find it), you aim your iPad or iPhone at the finished puzzle and start the app. By tapping the screen, you get white dots of "snow", and the scene changes to a winter scene. If you tap too much, you get a nasty and disconcerting--but harmless--little surprise!

This puzzle, although difficult, is much easier than the [[ASIN:B007ADICS2 Paris, 1000-Pieces Augmented Reality Puzzle]], which I found far less enjoyable because of the extreme difficulty of the photo. However, the Paris puzzle has a much more elaborate and impressive Augmented Reality portion, which shows and describes the major landmarks of Paris as seen from the Eiffel Tower. I really believe that jigsaw puzzles like these have educational value--doing jigsaw puzzles as a child helped me later with high school solid geometry and with art classes.

title: An Extremely Difficult Puzzle, Even for Jigsaw Puzzle Fanatics, Because of Puzzle Photo Problems
text:
This Ravensburger "Rooftops of Paris" puzzle is probably the most difficult jigsaw puzzle that I've ever assembled. The manufacturing quality of the puzzle is superb--every piece slips easily into place when it is the correct piece, but not otherwise. But problems with the puzzle photo itself and the puzzle box photo increase the jigsaw's difficulty to the point where the puzzle is a chore--not a pleasure--to put together.

First, the puzzle box photo: you must work the left and right corner segments of the puzzle without ANY photo, because the puzzle box photo has descriptive graphics (a "video-animation" banner and a photo of an iPhone display) that completely cover large segments of the puzzle photo. A tiny supplementary photo appears on the side of the box, but the puzzle photo's lower edge is cut off.

Second, the puzzle photo: the photo detail on most of the puzzle pieces is quite tiny, and in many areas, the photo itself is out of focus. Consequently, to have any hope of finding the location of a piece, you must look very closely at both the piece and the puzzle box photo. With the most out-of-focus pieces, you often cannot tell whether the piece is turned with the correct edge facing up. I actually started with the nearly one-color sky, because it was the easiest part. (I like doing single-color puzzles from time to time, for practice with recognizing puzzle piece shapes and orientations.)

After finishing the sky, I discovered that I could NOT assemble the remaining puzzle normally, by looking at the pieces, locating the ones that seemed to belong together, and assembling the pieces into various areas of the picture. Instead, most of the photo detail is so tiny that the "pictures" on the pieces look like parts of an abstract impressionist painting, and even obscure the shapes of the pieces. Worse yet, the pieces are often cut along color change points (for example, a mostly black piece may join with yellow tabs extending from a mostly yellow piece). In the end, I sorted all of the pieces by general color AND camera focus, and worked the puzzle in horizontal and diagonal bands, using a magnifying glass at times to peer at the box photo and the pieces.

The Augmented Reality feature is rather nice, although I had to Google "AR Puzzle" to find the free app in the iTunes store. (The app works only with the iPad and iPhone; it does NOT work with the iPod Touch.) To view the promised Paris nightscape, you must "Start" the app from the button on the menu screen. This turns on the camera; then you activate the app by focusing the camera on the Eiffel Tower. Thankfully, you can focus on the Eiffel Tower in the puzzle box photo as well as the Eiffel Tower in the assembled puzzle, so you don't have to finish the whole puzzle if you only want to see the AR app.

Once you activate the app, you see a fisheye photo with the Eiffel Tower lit up. Then you must move your iPad or iPhone to a vertical position to see the 360 degree nightscape that surrounds the central fisheye. By spinning in a chair, or just turning yourself around in a circle (and holding your device facing you vertically), you see the night view of Paris from the top of the Eiffel Tower. Circles identify major points of interest (e.g., Arc de Triomphe, Louvre, Notre Dame de Paris). When you touch one of the circles, a page of historical, travel-guide-type description of the famous landmark comes up.

Whenever I'm working on a jigsaw puzzle, I get rather obsessed with finishing it. Assembling this puzzle (only 1000 pieces!) took me almost five full days--and I didn't enjoy the process, even though I normally love working the hardest jigsaws. In addition, the Augmented Reality feature is largely a gimmick that doesn't add much to the jigsaw experience. For these reasons, I rate this extremely well-made, extremely difficult puzzle at just 3 stars ("It's okay" on the Amazon scale).

title: Deliciously Difficult for Experienced Jigsaw Puzzlers
text:
Even for jigsaw puzzle fanatics, this Ravensburger "Vintage Vacations" puzzle is deliciously difficult! At first glance, it looks easy, because there are 10 different travel posters shown, and the poster scenes are separated by straight black lines. However, the sheer number of pieces converts this "easy" puzzle into a challenging one. It took me nearly 7 hours just to sort the 2000 pieces (by color) to my satisfaction.

Bear in mind, this puzzle is HUGE. The finished size is 29-1/2" by 38-1/2", which means you need a large work table or dining room table to assemble it comfortably. Because I have limited space, I put it together on a work table that was just large enough to hold the finished puzzle. Thus I had to work from trays of sorted puzzle pieces (disposable plastic dinner and salad plates will do), and this slowed me down. It took me about 10 days, working half days, to complete the puzzle.

To my mind, jigsaw puzzles are highly educational. They teach shape and color recognition, and mental rotation of shapes. With this particular puzzle, the assembly goes faster when you pick up its logic: one travel photo has bathers in a pool, another has bathers on a beach; one photo has motor tours, another has a power boat race; two photos show city tourist spots; and so on.

The Ravensburger puzzle is high quality, as advertised. Each piece is unique as to color and shape, and the pieces are totally interlocking--no pieces have those annoying curved edges that just slide up against each other. The detail of the tiny people is amazing. Also, the puzzle has airplanes, boats, clouds, and different colors that break up the larger areas of sky and water, so that the puzzle never seems impossible or boring.

title: One year old loved it
text: My niece just turned one and tore into it. She loved all the animals and piling the cubes on top of each other then knocking them dowm. Kept her occupied for a good half hour. Highly recommend. Tx u

title: Light heat, perfect for pain
text:
Like - cute, soft, steady mild heat, manuverable
Dislike - stinks, heat lasts 30 minutes, not an hour

title: Super cute
text: Very cute. Slight disappointment as picture shows 'fur' to be a bit curlier than ut actually is.

title: Cute
text: Cute

title: cute
text: This is adorable. Even my husband thought it was cute and he never pays attention to anything. It is not snuggly as the bottom is hard in order to accommodate the batteries and for the elephant to be able to sit, but it the top is soft and the floppy ears make it unique.

title: Disappointed
text: Knuckles nose fell off and and tails arm arrived stained

title: Difficult to turn
text: Difficult for child to turn on there own cheap plastic cracked when trying to turn

title: Great quality
text: Great toy to keep kids entertained for hours quality is great for the price easy to assemble and disassemble

title: Waste of money
text: Didn't stick at All waste of money

title: Summer fun
text: Great sensory activity! Kept my son entertained for hours

title: Tiny swing
text: Child outgrows swing fast and close to the ground so inconvenient if your child has long legs

title: Adorable set- just can't believe runway and case are made of PAPER
text: This set was pretty pricey- so imagine my surprise when we are opening Christmas morning, and the entire runway is made of CARDBOARD‚Ä¶ I honestly would not even call it cardboard bc it was not thick enough to be cardboard! Whole reason for the purchase was for the runway portion of it, but can see that will be crushed quickly and this will not last long as a children's toy!

title: Great toys for bored minds.
text: This year, as a family, we're trying to use items less that don't involve screens (phones, tvs, tablets, computers). My son saw an ad for this type of toy and used his allowance to purchase it and he loves it! We have spent hours building and showing off our creations. The whole family sat around the table and spent time together creating neat ideas. We really recommend this as a present! Your kids will love them and it helps them use their imaginations which is always better than a child sitting on a tablet, phone, or computer watching some other kid on YouTube play video games.

title: Fun toys for my 10 year old
text: Fun toys for my 10 year old. He loves Minecraft

title: Cute, but best used with supervision.
text: It's interesting that another reviewer mentioned this would be best suited for a grandparent's house, because I totally agree. I bought this for my grandkids, and thought about sending them home with it, but after seeing how tiny the pieces are (and how MANY there are), I thought better of it. I'll keep it here and supervise the little ones while we play with it. The scenes are cute, and I love the idea of it (and especially the built-in storage), but it's not as intuitive as I would have expected. In fact, it's a little overwhelming. My oldest granddaughter is 3, so we'll see how this particular toy holds her interest over time.

title: Super cute!
text: This is not a very extensive set (there aren't even any instructions, or suggestions for setting up the scene), but it is SO CUTE. Kids don't need to have seen Jurassic Park to enjoy playing with the dinosaur or mini Chris Pratt. The car is awesome, plus the tower and walkie talkie - kids will figure out pretty quickly how to engage in imaginative play with these. And honestly, it gave me a good chuckle to know how actual movie scenes might play out with these pieces. Really cute and fun set appropriate for any ages.

title: A big hit!
text: This has been an absolute winner with my grandkids, partly because it's suitable & entertaining for a pretty wide age span - babies, toddlers, and preschoolers. The train comes with blocks you can load on, or empty it and have the kids put their own toys in for a ride. We also like the flexibility of adding the caboose or not - there are just a variety of ways to play with this! The songs and music are pretty enjoyable (not annoying like many toys), and I appreciate the volume control. This train rolls along very well on either hardwood or carpet, which I like since the kids can get frustrated when a toy stalls on the carpet. This toy looked so simple from the packaging, but it's turned out to be a lot of fun and a big hit!

title: Another winner from Battat!
text: I'm growing to really love the Battat line of toys! This doctor kit is no exception. As with their other products, I love the colors, durability, and design of the pieces in this kit. There are all the standard items - stethoscope, "shot," otoscope (for looking in the ear), etc - with some fun additions like the tweezers and basin. The case is incredibly sturdy - my 2yo granddaughter keeps standing on it, so we should know. It's been so fun to watch her examine her toys, dolls, and even her baby brother. Another winner from Battat!

title: Durable, creative, affordable.
text: I can't decide on my favorite part of these toys - the beautiful colors, the sturdy construction, or the awesome, unique additions to this set (ie: hand mixer, rolling pin, dish rack, etc). This really is a *fabulous* collection, a total upgrade for your child's imaginative play (and at a great price!).

title: Cute toys, great use of letter and color recognition.
text: These have been so much fun to discover with my 2.5yo granddaughter. I love the color coordination - the color of the letter, color of the acorn top, and color of the item all match. This has provided a whole other way to use these while we play (ie: sorting, color recognition). I also love that the upper case of the letter is on the outside, and the lower case is on the inside of the acorn top. I see some reviewers commenting on the choice of items for each letter, and while some feel a little odd/non-traditional, I don't see it as a big issue. Two reasons I deducted a star for this rating: (1) the acorn tops do not stay on when these are placed in a bag - and how else do you expect to store or transport these? Every time we try to put these away, it just become a salad of toys, acorns, and tops. (2) These smell _horrible_ for a while after unpacking - like, 2 or 3 days of airing them out before the odor didn't hit the back of our throats. Because of this, I recommend opening them before you give them to your child.

title: Not much use as a toy.
text: I did receive all 4, unlike many reviewers here, so I'm glad for that. BUT...I'm just not sure what the point of these are, and the few children I've attempted to give them to have felt the same (none of them wanted them!). They are a strange, tacky material - one drop on the floor, and now you've got dirt/pet hair/whatever attached. No parts of these toys move, making them pretty drab to play with. And if your child isn't totally familiar with the superhero, the reaction is anti-climactic (FYI: in addition to the more recognizable Harley Quinn, Bat Girl, Super Girl, and Wonder Woman, you have Katana (wearing the white mask) and Bumblebee (yellow and brown hair).) I can only imagine these will be either dropped to the bottom of the toy bin, or else maybe put on a shelf by a collector. In either case, not much use as a toy.

title: Fantastic addition to Osmo's line of products.
text: We had the very first generation of Osmo, and my son loved it. But the apps and games soon became too much for our old iPad to keep up with, and we upgrade our phones much more frequently than our tablets. That's why I was so excited to see this new base for iPhone! Not only will it be easier to keep up with all Osmo has to offer, but now it's much more portable, too. As with the original base, this one is sturdy and wonderfully designed, and is simple for my son to operate on his own. He was playing his favorite Osmo games in no time, and it was great to see him get excited about this product and company all over again. Thanks for this addition, Osmo!

title: Just as likely to frustrate as entertain.
text: I have generally enjoyed the Battat line of toddler and preschool toys, but this one has a design flaw - and missed opportunity - that leave me less enthusiastic. First of all, I'm not sure the ramp is really all that much "easier" for little hands to put the toys in/out of the bus. But as long as it's there, I wish they would have included a child with a wheelchair. The toy figures are quite diverse - I would have loved to see that go a step further. But the design flaw is really what has me scratching my head. The seats on the bus are recessed, but are too large for the little figures to actually fit into. Once you start moving the bus, the figures fall and scatter. I'm not sure Battat understood how totally frustrating that is for little kids - especially since they don't just keep these rolling along quietly, slowly on the floor, but tend to take toy vehicles "off road" and even flying up into outer space. I _really_ wish these little figure snapped into the seats and stayed put.

title: Nice intro set, terrible instructions.
text: We've had a lot of laughs with our 10yo son using this magic set. There are many different elements, his favorites probably being the fake thumb, wand, and cups. But the booklets that come with it are not very helpful for a kid to read on his own - just really dense and convoluted. Instead, our son has watched some videos and also come up with ways to use the materials here in his own way. This is a nice set to introduce a child to magic, but is probably not as comprehensive or well-crafted as an older child might want if they get serious about doing polished tricks.

title: Repetition and cause/effect are fun for toddlers.
text: I love having a toy for my granddaughter that is ready to play with right out of the box! I like the colors and design of this set, even the little "star" motif on the hammer and in the toy itself. My 2yo granddaughter loves to play with this - something about the repetition and the cause/effect is somewhat hypnotizing to her. I do wish all four balls went down the track - the little "door" that opens on the far left chute is tricky for small hands to open & close, and there's not much to be excited about when the ball goes straight down. Still, this is getting a lot of play at our house, and I'm very satisfied.

title: Great toy that will grow with our grandkids.
text:
5 stars for the toy itself. 0 stars for the directions - they are awful! The pictures are in blurry black and white, and the wording is confusing. It took me far too long to put together, but I was impressed by the finished product.

First of all - this is big! Look carefully at the specs on this toy to see if it will fit well (or dominate) your play space. The colors and designs are bright and cheerful, which I like. There are a few specific mechanical steps to make this work right with the car, and I worried that it would be too complicated for my 2yo granddaughter. (1) The arm needs to be clicked down into position, (2) you need to wind the car up the ramp (and the crank for that is tricky - if you let go just a little, it slides back to the bottom), then once the car slides down the ramp into the cradle you need to (3) release the arm for the catapult to launch down the second slide. Again - sounds complicated, right? But my granddaughter mastered it in no time! I was surprised and happy about that.

I was also very happy that she played with this over and over. She never seemed to get bored with it. The little car plays music and phrases as it goes along, and even when all the steps didn't go perfectly (ie: the car crashed), my granddaughter was amused. One quick note: some of the joints seem to come apart easily, and since toddlers are a little rough, we needed to keep an eye on this. Still, this will be a great toy that grows with our grandkids!

title: Major win from K'NEX.
text: It's been a few years since my husband and son put another K'NEX roller coaster together, and I wasn't sure if I was going to be able to talk my husband into this one. His experience before - though they did ultimately finish - was frustrating and time consuming. I'm wondering if K'NEX has made some improvements in the meantime, because my husband and son said this set was *much* more enjoyable! The parts were sturdier, fit together better, and the instructions were much clearer. It still gave them an afternoon of dedicated father/son time to build it, and they were SO happy with the result! This is a super exciting coaster, made even better by the fact that it can run vertical or horizontal. AND...it glows in the dark! My 9yo and husband are thrilled with themselves, and aside from trying to find space for this 2.5' colossus, I'm happy too. Major win from K'NEX.

title: Gathering dust.
text:
My 8yo son fancies himself a "master builder," so I was interested to see how he would enjoy this set. It boasts "gears and axles and joints," etc, which I thought might really differentiate these from the LEGO sets he usually plays with.
The set itself is fine. There are a ton of pieces, and though it comes in a container, they are hard to fit in there after you start playing with them. I'm not sure why, but after just a few times playing with them, this set is now gathering dust on the bookshelf. My son has just not been that interested. They are a bit larger and almost more clunky than LEGOs, and I think the bright coloring almost makes it skew a little more juvenile.
These would probably be a big hit with another kid, but my son just wasn't very interested.

title: Great for projects with young children!
text: This caddy set is fantastic for craft projects with a group of kids, or for in-class at a preschool. The cups fit perfectly into the base, but I was particularly impressed that even separated from the base, the cups are sturdy and do not fall over as the scissors are grabbed and returned. The colors on the handles are bright and consistent. The ruler feature on the blade is interesting, but I'm not sure if it's particularly useful for the target age group. And I didn't quite understand the spot where you can customize each pair of scissors with a name - trying to remove the tiny cover and insert a tiny slip of paper with a name took more time than it was worth. Far simpler to just write a child's name with a Sharpie on the blade itself. Overall, though, these are quality scissors and offer up a ton of potential for projects with young children!

title: Cute, colorful set.
text: Our 4yo niece has been playing with this set and really enjoys it. Once set up, it's much smaller than it looks on the box, and to get it configured just right, an adult definitely needs to be involved. Either that, or an older child maybe 6-9yo would be able to do it on their own. The moving parts are very fun, and when our niece brought it to daycare, it was a big hit. She love the little figures that came with it, and has been having a lot of fun with this cute, colorful set.

title: Sturdy and engaging.
text: This set is sturdy, engaging, and quite large. It's made of quality materials, and the details are great. I like that the trains are the magnetic-connector type, and that they are not battery-operated. My 7yo son has had tons of imaginative play with this train set. Though we built it on the floor, he asked to have it raised up, so now it is taking up our entire dining table. Make sure you have room for this train set! Also, be careful in unpacking that you don't lose/throw away the directions. They are on a flimsy piece of paper that is easy to miss, and without it, it's difficult to figure these tracks out - they only fit in one configuration. At this point, I am considering marking the tracks in some manner to indicate how they attach, just so I don't have to fish out the directions each time my son wants to move the set. The set works with other tracks, and I can see how this could easily expand into a whole train world. This is a nice, solid, well-made train set!

title: Just "ok"
text: Our family loves word games, and I was hoping this would be one we could add to our favorites. The idea is similar to other games out there - (first thing I think of is Scattergories) - where you have to quickly think of words that start with a specific letter for a particular category. In this case, the category might be "pizza toppings," and then you call out an item, tapping down the letter it starts with, and hand it off to another person who has to call out another item starting with another (non-tapped) letter, etc etc, until the timer buzzes. The concept is generally ok. But there are better versions of this type of game out there. More creative, I guess. And I honestly do NOT like the design of the Tapple board that gets handed around. It's nearly impossible to quickly pass it off without accidentally tapping down one of the letters in the process. Big design flaw. We *have* found an unexpected use for this game - it's been a fun way to help my 6yo expand his vocabulary. We don't play the game, per se, but do use it without the timer and have him think up different words within each category. But for a group game? I'll pass.

title: Could use a few tweaks.
text: I had hoped to play this more with my 6yo son, who is an advanced reader and needs more practice at home with recognizing and building vocabulary (his Kinder class - packed at 30 kids - isn't very challenging for him in this respect). Unfortunately, while the design of this game is super cute, it wasn't practical for his smaller, somewhat clumsy hands, and he lost patience with the logistics of how to play this game. I did find my older kids a little more adept at maneuvering the pieces, etc, and it was a bit more fun to play with them. I like that everything is kept together in the canister, and I think much of the basic design is good, but could possibly use some more tweaks to make it more appealing to younger players.

title: Not what we expected.
text: We expected this to be a great way for our 6yo son to be creative, but instead, it's gathering dust on the shelf. It's messier than we expected and actually has a lot of "parts" between the various uses. Things get scattered easily when he takes it out to play, instead of just being a clear-cut, intuitive toy. As other reviewers have said, it's also not very easy to erase what he's already drawn, making it more trouble than it's worth. Forget the light-up board feature of this - my son would rather (a) play with a plain dry-erase board, or (b) play with a good old fashioned Lite Brite more than he would like to play with this again.

title: Disappointing
text: Our family loves playing UNO, and I thought this version would be especially fun for my active 5yo son. Unfortunately, what I thought would be some fast-paced fun turned into an incredibly annoying experience! This game is SO LOUD. It's just too much. I searched in vain for a volume button, of course there isn't one. The game itself is also just unnecessarily complicated. I was really disappointed! The traditional UNO game is simple and fun, and about 1,000 times better than this "new and improved" version of it. Save your money, some batteries, and your sanity and stick with the regular deck of cards!

title: Not as satisfying or sturdy as I hoped
text:
[[VIDEOID:ef20df3944f457bd2d8b3823dca38341]] Meh, I am not a huge fan of this toy. It's made of 3 distinct pieces: the base, the middle, and the circular piece at the top. The circular part on the top is not very satisfying to slide back and forth, and the piece itself can easily come off. In fact, all 3 pieces come apart pretty easily.

The toy feels sturdy and has a nice weight to it, but the magnets feel kind of weak, especially the top and middle magnets. Skip this one.

title: A nice fidget toy. Wish it were a bit heavier
text:
[[VIDEOID:7fc70e964c5a034f850f763c951d1554]] I really enjoy playing with this. The sliding clicks have a great feel to them, and the buttons are very tactile. I've had it for a few weeks now and it is holding up great. My main issue is that the "metal" material they use feels pretty light. I'd guess it's aluminum and not stainless steel (which is what I assumed when I saw the model name was "AB-SS". Also, I haven't been able to get it to gyrate like in the listing photo.

Overall, I like this. A more solid finish would have put it to 5 stars.

title: Nice little fidget toy
text:
[[VIDEOID:aa6d5990fc416c770b2375a9349c7998]] This is a decent fidget toy. Probably in my top 3, albeit my experience is limited. It feels very solid and sturdy in your hand, and I would expect this to last for a long time. I've had it for about 3 weeks and (if you wipe the fingerprints off), it looks as good as new.

It spins in either direction, which is nice for when you absentmindedly pick it up. My only gripe with this is that the spinning doesn't feel as satisfying as I'd have hoped. I wish it felt a bit more tactile. All that said, I still like it.

title: Satisfying to use, but not very durable
text: [[VIDEOID:4a5f2a98d4b43e3784ea67502323398e]] I got this about 3 weeks ago, and for the past week or so, it has kind of been falling apart. In the beginning, it was spinning really smoothly and would spin for a long time, but now it has begun falling apart. The big piece in the middle (which spins), becomes unhinged from the top and bottom corners, which removes the smooth spinning (see pic). So you have to click it back in place, which becomes pretty annoying, especially given how recently I got this. Also, this thing is a fingerprint magnet. Overall, I'd pass on this.

title: Solid fidget toy. But has a few drawbacks.
text:
[[VIDEOID:ce48efee967b05d34fa5c0d5b0f4e24b]] This is among the better fidget toys I've used.

I'll start off with my gripes:

First, after fidgeting this for a few minutes, the screw becomes loose and you have to re-tighten. If it becomes too lose, the cards begin separating, which is annoying. This normally wouldn't be a problem, but it loosens within a few minutes, so it's just annoying to have to constantly be re-tightening it. Secondly, I'm not a huge fan of the metallic sound it makes when you slide the cards open/closed. This is definitely personal preference, but I would have preferred a more muted sound. Lastly, because it's heavy, when I drop it, I get nervous that it's going to leave a dent in my wood desk (it hasn't).

Despite my gripes, it is pretty satisfying to play with. I enjoy it.

title: I really wanted to like this
text:
This came with the main spinner, but I was surprised to see that it also came with a small plastic spinner as well. Some other review mentioned a laser light, but mine came with a plastic spinner instead.

I have several gripes about this thing. Both things, really.

First off, the size. The metal one is a little large to reliably spin with one hand. The plastic one is actually much easier to use with one hand. Although I don't love the design. I wish it had points sticking out instead of the rounded edges.

Secondly, because the metal one has a spinner at each point, it's hard to get leverage for the spin because the smaller spinners will spin instead. This is more of a problem if you are trying to hold and spin with the same hand.

That said, it feels very solid and well made. It is heavy and feels high quality, but I can't enjoy it because of the issues mentioned above.

title: Great BPA-free food grade sensory toy with entertainment value; rated for 18 months+
text:
This is a great BPA-free food grade sensory toy for toddlers. It is rated for toddlers 18 months+. It looks like a spaceship with tentacles. The tentacles are silicone and can be pulled through the "spaceship." There are three fidget circles on one side of the perimeter. On the other side, there is one button that, when pressed, moves from hole to hole.

I really like this but it is important to supervise the child when using this. Also, be careful because it can be thrown easily by grabbing onto the tentacles.

The current price of $9.09 ($13.99 minus 35%) is a steal as most are around $14. I gave one of these to my neighbor's son and he absolutely loves it.

title: Simple BPA-free food grade sensory toy with entertainment value
text:

This one looks like an airplane with tentacles. The tentacles are silicone and can be pulled through the body of the "aircraft." There are some others like this that have fidget circles and buttons but this one does not. It is a basic unit.

I really like this but it is important to supervise the child when using this. Also, be careful because it can be thrown easily by grabbing onto the tentacles.

The current price of $8.99 ($10.99 minus $2) is reasonable for this. For those interested in units with buttons but a little more expensive, then take a look at this [[ASIN:B0B62KX3F9 one]].

title: Adorable & flexible silicone baby dumbbell teether and rattle in one
text:
This is a purple baby rattle/teether dumbbell. It is so cute. It bends and the ends are the rattle. This has to be sterilized before first use either in boiling water for 2 minutes or in the top rack of the dishwasher. It is rated for babies 6 months and above but I suggest supervising during use. It is BPA free and free of phthalates, lead, and cadmium per the box.

This is made of 100% food-grade silicone and is made in China.

Overall, this is a cute teether and rattle. It is also great for cute baby pictures posing with this dumbbell. The current price of ($8.99 minus 10%) is reasonable for this as a previous one I ordered from another vendor was several dollars more.

NOTE - Always supervise a baby when using this because if the child throws this, it could hurt another child.

title: Great food grade partial silicone sensory toy with entertainment value; rated for 6-18 months
text:
This is a great sensory toy for toddlers. It is rated, per the Amazon site, for toddlers from 6-18 months old. It looks like a cat-shaped face with tentacles. The tentacles are silicone and can be pulled through the unit. There are seven fidget circles on one side of the perimeter. On the other side, there is one button that, when pressed, moves from hole to hole. There are also rings on another side.

I have tried several of these units recently, and this one in particular, has more entertainment value due to the additional fidget circles and rings.

I really like this but it is important to supervise the child when using this. Also, be careful because it can be thrown easily by grabbing onto the tentacles.

The current price of $11.19 ($13.99 minus 20%) is very reasonable for this.
